     </table>
     <p>
      The
      <b>
       Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </b>
      (
      <b>
       MIT
      </b>
      ) is a
      <a href="/wiki/Private_university" title="Private university">
       private
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Research_university" title="Research university">
       research university
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts" title="Cambridge, Massachusetts">
       Cambridge, Massachusetts
      </a>
      . Founded in 1861 in response to the increasing
      <a href="/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States" title="Technological and industrial history of the United States">
       industrialization of the United States
      </a>
      , MIT adopted a European
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_European_research_universities" title="History of European research universities">
       polytechnic university model
      </a>
      and stressed laboratory instruction in applied science and engineering. Researchers worked on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whirlwind_(computer)" title="Whirlwind (computer)">
       computers
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">
       radar
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Inertial_navigation_system" title="Inertial navigation system">
       inertial guidance
      </a>
      during
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
       Cold War
      </a>
      . Post-war defense research contributed to the rapid expansion of the faculty and campus under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Killian" title="James Killian">
       James Killian
      </a>
      . The current 168-acre (68.0 ha) campus opened in 1916 and extends over 1 mile (1.6 km) along the northern bank of the
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_River" title="Charles River">
       Charles River basin
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The Institute is traditionally known for its research and education in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School_of_Science,_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="School of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       physical sciences
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_School_of_Engineering" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology School of Engineering">
       engineering
      </a>
      , and more recently in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT_Biology_Department" title="MIT Biology Department">
       biology
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Department_of_Economics" title="MIT Department of Economics">
       economics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Linguistics" title="Linguistics">
       linguistics
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Sloan_School_of_Management" title="MIT Sloan School of Management">
       management
      </a>
      as well. It is often cited as among the world's top universities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloomberg1_10-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bloomberg1-10">
        [10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morgan1_11-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-morgan1-11">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclopedia1_12-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-encyclopedia1-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica1_13-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-britannica1-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The "Engineers" sponsor 31 sports, most teams of which compete in the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association" title="National Collegiate Athletic Association">
       NCAA
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA)" title="Division III (NCAA)">
       Division III
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/New_England_Women%27s_and_Men%27s_Athletic_Conference" title="New England Women's and Men's Athletic Conference">
       New England Women's and Men's Athletic Conference
      </a>
      ; the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Division_I_(NCAA)" title="Division I (NCAA)">
       Division I
      </a>
      rowing programs compete as part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Association_of_Rowing_Colleges" title="Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges">
       EARC
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Association_of_Women%27s_Rowing_Colleges" title="Eastern Association of Women's Rowing Colleges">
       EAWRC
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      As of 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_university_affiliation" title="List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation">
       85 Nobel laureates
      </a>
      , 52
      <a href="/wiki/National_Medal_of_Science" title="National Medal of Science">
       National Medal of Science
      </a>
      recipients, 65
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marshall_Scholars" title="Marshall Scholars">
       Marshall Scholars
      </a>
      , 45
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhodes_Scholars" title="Rhodes Scholars">
       Rhodes Scholars
      </a>
      , 38
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MacArthur_Fellow" title="MacArthur Fellow">
       MacArthur Fellows
      </a>
      , 34
      <a href="/wiki/Astronaut" title="Astronaut">
       astronauts
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Turing_Award_laureates_by_university_affiliation" title="List of Turing Award laureates by university affiliation">
       19 Turing award winners
      </a>
      , 16
      <a href="/wiki/Chief_Scientist_of_the_U.S._Air_Force" title="Chief Scientist of the U.S. Air Force">
       Chief Scientists of the U.S. Air Force
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Fields_Medal_winners_by_university_affiliation" title="List of Fields Medal winners by university affiliation">
       6 Fields Medalists
      </a>
      have been affiliated with MIT. The school has a strong
      <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">
       entrepreneurial culture
      </a>
      , and the aggregated revenues of companies founded by MIT alumni would rank as the eleventh-largest economy in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="History of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       History of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Foundation_and_vision">
       Foundation and vision
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Foundation and vision">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="rquote floatright" role="presentation" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-style:none; float:right; margin:0.5em 0.75em; width:33%;">
      <tr style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;">
       <td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:'Times New Roman',serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">
        “
       </td>
       <td style="padding:0 10px;">
        .... a school of industrial science aiding the advancement, development and practical application of science in connection with arts, agriculture, manufactures, and commerce.
       </td>
       <td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:'Times New Roman',serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; text-align:right; vertical-align:bottom; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">
        ”
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td class="rquotecite" colspan="3" style="padding-top:10px; font-size:smaller; line-height:1em; text-align:right;">
        <cite>
         — Act to Incorporate the Massachusetts Institute of Technology,
         <br/>
         <i>
          Acts of 1861, Chapter 183
         </i>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
          <a href="#cite_note-16">
           [16]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="757" data-file-width="1500" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg/220px-MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg/330px-MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg/440px-MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Boston_19th_c_byEdward_L_Allen_BPL_2351553844.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stereographic_card" title="Stereographic card">
         Stereographic card
        </a>
        showing an MIT mechanical drafting studio, 19th century (photo by
        <a href="/wiki/Edward_L._Allen" title="Edward L. Allen">
         E.L. Allen
        </a>
        , left/right inverted)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mass._Inst._Technology,_by_E._L._Allen.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1429" data-file-width="2737" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png/220px-Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png/330px-Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png/440px-Mass._Inst._Technology%2C_by_E._L._Allen.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mass._Inst._Technology,_by_E._L._Allen.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Original
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rogers_Building_(MIT)" title="Rogers Building (MIT)">
         Rogers Building
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Back_Bay,_Boston" title="Back Bay, Boston">
         Back Bay, Boston
        </a>
        , 19th century
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1859, a proposal was submitted to the
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court" title="Massachusetts General Court">
       Massachusetts General Court
      </a>
      to use newly filled lands in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Back_Bay,_Boston,_Massachusetts" title="Back Bay, Boston, Massachusetts">
       Back Bay
      </a>
      , Boston for a "
      <a href="/wiki/Conservatoire_national_des_arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers" title="Conservatoire national des arts et métiers">
       Conservatory of Art and Science
      </a>
      ", but the proposal failed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
       <a href="#cite_note-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A charter for the
      <a href="/wiki/Incorporation_(business)" title="Incorporation (business)">
       incorporation
      </a>
      of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, proposed by
      <a href="/wiki/William_Barton_Rogers" title="William Barton Rogers">
       William Barton Rogers
      </a>
      , was signed by the
      <a href="/wiki/John_Albion_Andrew" title="John Albion Andrew">
       governor of Massachusetts
      </a>
      on April 10, 1861.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Rogers, a professor from the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">
       University of Virginia
      </a>
      , wanted to establish an institution to address rapid scientific and technological advances.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
      He did not wish to found a
      <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">
       professional school
      </a>
      , but a combination with elements of both professional and
      <a href="/wiki/Liberal_education" title="Liberal education">
       liberal education
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis_Report_22-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lewis_Report-22">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
      proposing that:
     </p>
     <blockquote>
      <p>
       The true and only practicable object of a polytechnic school is, as I conceive, the teaching, not of the minute details and manipulations of the arts, which can be done only in the workshop, but the inculcation of those scientific principles which form the basis and explanation of them, and along with this, a full and methodical review of all their leading processes and operations in connection with physical laws.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      The Rogers Plan reflected the
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_European_research_universities#European_university_models_in_the_19th_and_20th_centuries" title="History of European research universities">
       German research university model
      </a>
      , emphasizing an independent faculty engaged in research, as well as instruction oriented around seminars and laboratories.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_developments">
       Early developments
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Early developments">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="626" data-file-width="742" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg/330px-%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg/440px-%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%98%D0%A2_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%81_1905.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A 1905 map of MIT's Boston campus
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Two days after the charter was issued, the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter" title="Battle of Fort Sumter">
       first battle
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">
       Civil War
      </a>
      broke out. After a long delay through the war years, MIT's first classes were held in the Mercantile Building in Boston in 1865.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The new institute was founded as part of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Morrill_Land-Grant_Colleges_Act" title="Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act">
       Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act
      </a>
      to fund institutions "to promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial classes", and was a land-grant school.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LoC_28-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LoC-28">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1863 under the same act, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts founded the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Massachusetts_Amherst#History" title="University of Massachusetts Amherst">
       Massachusetts Agricultural College
      </a>
      , which developed as the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Massachusetts_Amherst" title="University of Massachusetts Amherst">
       University of Massachusetts Amherst
      </a>
      . In 1866, the proceeds from land sales went toward new buildings in the Back Bay.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BostonTech1_29-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BostonTech1-29">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT was informally called "Boston Tech".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BostonTech1_29-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-BostonTech1-29">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The institute adopted the
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_European_research_universities" title="History of European research universities">
       European polytechnic university model
      </a>
      and emphasized laboratory instruction from an early date.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite chronic financial problems, the institute saw growth in the last two decades of the 19th century under President
      <a href="/wiki/Francis_Amasa_Walker" title="Francis Amasa Walker">
       Francis Amasa Walker
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunbar1_31-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dunbar1-31">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Programs in electrical, chemical, marine, and sanitary engineering were introduced,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Munroe1923a_33-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Munroe1923a-33">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      new buildings were built, and the size of the student body increased to more than one thousand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunbar1_31-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dunbar1-31">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The curriculum drifted to a vocational emphasis, with less focus on theoretical science.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The fledgling school still suffered from chronic financial shortages which diverted the attention of the MIT leadership. During these "Boston Tech" years, MIT faculty and alumni rebuffed
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
       Harvard University
      </a>
      president (and former MIT faculty)
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_W._Eliot" title="Charles W. Eliot">
       Charles W. Eliot
      </a>
      's repeated attempts to merge MIT with Harvard College's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lawrence_Scientific_School" title="Lawrence Scientific School">
       Lawrence Scientific School
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There would be at least six attempts to absorb MIT into Harvard.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexander_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Alexander-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In its cramped Back Bay location, MIT could not afford to expand its overcrowded facilities, driving a desperate search for a new campus and funding. Eventually the MIT Corporation approved a formal agreement to merge with Harvard, over the vehement objections of MIT faculty, students, and alumni.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexander_36-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Alexander-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, a 1917 decision by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court effectively put an end to the merger scheme.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexander_36-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Alexander-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Eastman_plaque.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3869" data-file-width="2571" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/George_Eastman_plaque.jpg/170px-George_Eastman_plaque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/George_Eastman_plaque.jpg/255px-George_Eastman_plaque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/George_Eastman_plaque.jpg/340px-George_Eastman_plaque.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Eastman_plaque.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Plaque in Building 6 honoring
        <a href="/wiki/George_Eastman" title="George Eastman">
         George Eastman
        </a>
        , founder of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastman_Kodak" title="Eastman Kodak">
         Eastman Kodak
        </a>
        , who was revealed as the anonymous "Mr. Smith" who helped maintain MIT's independence
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1916, the MIT administration and the MIT charter crossed the Charles River on the ceremonial barge
      <i>
       Bucentaur
      </i>
      built for the occasion,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      to signify MIT's move to a spacious new campus largely consisting of
      <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">
       filled land
      </a>
      on a mile-long tract along the Cambridge side of the Charles River.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">
       neoclassical
      </a>
      "New Technology" campus was designed by
      <a href="/wiki/William_W._Bosworth" title="William W. Bosworth">
       William W. Bosworth
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and had been funded largely by anonymous donations from a mysterious "Mr. Smith", starting in 1912. In January 1920, the donor was revealed to be the industrialist
      <a href="/wiki/George_Eastman" title="George Eastman">
       George Eastman
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Rochester,_New_York" title="Rochester, New York">
       Rochester, New York
      </a>
      , who had invented methods of film production and processing, and founded
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastman_Kodak" title="Eastman Kodak">
       Eastman Kodak
      </a>
      . Between 1912 and 1920, Eastman donated $20 million ($236.6 million in 2015 dollars) in cash and Kodak stock to MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Curricular_reforms">
       Curricular reforms
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Curricular reforms">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In the 1930s, President
      <a href="/wiki/Karl_Taylor_Compton" title="Karl Taylor Compton">
       Karl Taylor Compton
      </a>
      and Vice-President (effectively
      <a href="/wiki/Provost_(education)" title="Provost (education)">
       Provost
      </a>
      )
      <a href="/wiki/Vannevar_Bush" title="Vannevar Bush">
       Vannevar Bush
      </a>
      emphasized the importance of pure sciences like physics and chemistry and reduced the vocational practice required in shops and drafting studios.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lecuyer_43-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lecuyer-43">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Compton reforms "renewed confidence in the ability of the Institute to develop leadership in science as well as in engineering."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis_1949.2C_p._13._44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lewis_1949.2C_p._13.-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Unlike
      <a href="/wiki/Ivy_League" title="Ivy League">
       Ivy League
      </a>
      schools, MIT catered more to middle-class families, and depended more on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuition" title="Tuition">
       tuition
      </a>
      than on
      <a href="/wiki/Financial_endowment" title="Financial endowment">
       endowments
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Grant_(money)" title="Grant (money)">
       grants
      </a>
      for its funding.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The school was elected to the
      <a href="/wiki/Association_of_American_Universities" title="Association of American Universities">
       Association of American Universities
      </a>
      in 1934.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AAU_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AAU-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Still, as late as 1949, the Lewis Committee lamented in its report on the state of education at MIT that "the Institute is widely conceived as basically a vocational school", a "partly unjustified" perception the committee sought to change. The report comprehensively reviewed the undergraduate curriculum, recommended offering a broader education, and warned against letting engineering and government-sponsored research detract from the sciences and humanities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITTECHNOLOGYREVIEW_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITTECHNOLOGYREVIEW-48">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Humanities,_Arts,_and_Social_Sciences" title="MIT School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences">
       School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Sloan_School_of_Management" title="MIT Sloan School of Management">
       MIT Sloan School of Management
      </a>
      were formed in 1950 to compete with the powerful Schools of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Science" title="MIT School of Science">
       Science
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Engineering" title="MIT School of Engineering">
       Engineering
      </a>
      . Previously marginalized faculties in the areas of economics, management, political science, and linguistics emerged into cohesive and assertive departments by attracting respected professors and launching competitive graduate programs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchoolOfHASS_49-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SchoolOfHASS-49">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SloanSchool_50-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SloanSchool-50">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences continued to develop under the successive terms of the more
      <a href="/wiki/Humanities" title="Humanities">
       humanistically oriented
      </a>
      presidents
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Howard_W._Johnson" title="Howard W. Johnson">
       Howard W. Johnson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Wiesner" title="Jerome Wiesner">
       Jerome Wiesner
      </a>
      between 1966 and 1980.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Defense_research">
       Defense research
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Defense research">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      MIT's involvement in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_funding_of_science" title="Military funding of science">
       military research
      </a>
      surged during
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      . In 1941,
      <a href="/wiki/Vannevar_Bush" title="Vannevar Bush">
       Vannevar Bush
      </a>
      was appointed head of the federal
      <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Scientific_Research_and_Development" title="Office of Scientific Research and Development">
       Office of Scientific Research and Development
      </a>
      and directed funding to only a select group of universities, including MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zachary1_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Zachary1-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Engineers and scientists from across the country gathered at MIT's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radiation_Laboratory" title="Radiation Laboratory">
       Radiation Laboratory
      </a>
      , established in 1940 to assist the
      <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of the United Kingdom during World War II">
       British military
      </a>
      in developing
      <a href="/wiki/Cavity_magnetron" title="Cavity magnetron">
       microwave
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">
       radar
      </a>
      . The work done there significantly affected both the war and subsequent research in the area.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RadLab_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RadLab-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other defense projects included
      <a href="/wiki/Gyroscope" title="Gyroscope">
       gyroscope
      </a>
      -based and other complex
      <a href="/wiki/Control_system" title="Control system">
       control systems
      </a>
      for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gunsight" title="Gunsight">
       gunsight
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bombsight" title="Bombsight">
       bombsight
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inertial_navigation" title="Inertial navigation">
       inertial navigation
      </a>
      under
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stark_Draper" title="Charles Stark Draper">
       Charles Stark Draper
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stark_Draper_Laboratory" title="Charles Stark Draper Laboratory">
       Instrumentation Laboratory
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the development of a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digital_computer" title="Digital computer">
       digital computer
      </a>
      for flight simulations under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_Whirlwind" title="Project Whirlwind">
       Project Whirlwind
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/High-speed_photography" title="High-speed photography">
       high-speed
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Espionage_balloon" title="Espionage balloon">
       high-altitude
      </a>
      photography under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harold_Edgerton" title="Harold Edgerton">
       Harold Edgerton
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By the end of the war, MIT became the nation's largest wartime R&amp;D contractor (attracting some criticism of Bush),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zachary1_52-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Zachary1-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      employing nearly 4000 in the Radiation Laboratory alone
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RadLab_53-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RadLab-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and receiving in excess of $100 million ($1.2 billion in 2015 dollars) before 1946.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis_1949.2C_p._13._44-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lewis_1949.2C_p._13.-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Work on defense projects continued even after then. Post-war
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Research_funding" title="Research funding">
       government-sponsored research
      </a>
      at MIT included
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi_Automatic_Ground_Environment" title="Semi Automatic Ground Environment">
       SAGE
      </a>
      and guidance systems for
      <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile" title="Ballistic missile">
       ballistic missiles
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_Apollo" title="Project Apollo">
       Project Apollo
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="rquote floatright" role="presentation" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-style:none; float:right; margin:0.5em 0.75em; width:33%;">
      <tr style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;">
       <td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:'Times New Roman',serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">
        “
       </td>
       <td style="padding:0 10px;">
        ...a special type of educational institution which can be defined as a university polarized around science, engineering, and the arts. We might call it a university limited in its objectives but unlimited in the breadth and the thoroughness with which it pursues these objectives.
       </td>
       <td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:'Times New Roman',serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; text-align:right; vertical-align:bottom; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">
        ”
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td class="rquotecite" colspan="3" style="padding-top:10px; font-size:smaller; line-height:1em; text-align:right;">
        <cite>
         — MIT president
         <a href="/wiki/James_Rhyne_Killian" title="James Rhyne Killian">
          James Rhyne Killian
         </a>
         , 1949
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Killian_60-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Killian-60">
           [60]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </cite>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      These activities affected MIT profoundly. A 1949 report noted the lack of "any great slackening in the pace of life at the Institute" to match the return to peacetime, remembering the "academic tranquility of the prewar years", though acknowledging the significant contributions of military research to the increased emphasis on graduate education and rapid growth of personnel and facilities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The faculty doubled and the graduate student body quintupled during the terms of
      <a href="/wiki/Karl_Taylor_Compton" title="Karl Taylor Compton">
       Karl Taylor Compton
      </a>
      , president of MIT between 1930 and 1948;
      <a href="/wiki/James_Rhyne_Killian" title="James Rhyne Killian">
       James Rhyne Killian
      </a>
      , president from 1948 to 1957; and
      <a href="/wiki/Julius_Adams_Stratton" title="Julius Adams Stratton">
       Julius Adams Stratton
      </a>
      , chancellor from 1952 to 1957, whose institution-building strategies shaped the expanding university. By the 1950s, MIT no longer simply benefited the industries with which it had worked for three decades, and it had developed closer working relationships with new patrons, philanthropic foundations and the federal government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In late 1960s and early 1970s, student and faculty activists protested against the
      <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
       Vietnam War
      </a>
      and MIT's defense research.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ins_and_outs_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ins_and_outs-63">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In this period MIT's various departments were researching helicopters, smart bombs and counterinsurgency techniques for the war in Vietnam as well as guidance systems for nuclear missiles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Concerned_Scientists" title="Union of Concerned Scientists">
       Union of Concerned Scientists
      </a>
      was founded on March 4, 1969 during a meeting of faculty members and students seeking to shift the emphasis on military research toward environmental and social problems.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT ultimately divested itself from the Instrumentation Laboratory and moved all classified research off-campus to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lincoln_Laboratory" title="Lincoln Laboratory">
       Lincoln Laboratory
      </a>
      facility in 1973 in response to the protests.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The student body, faculty, and administration remained comparatively unpolarized during what was a tumultuous time for many other universities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ins_and_outs_63-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ins_and_outs-63">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Johnson was seen to be highly successful in leading his institution to "greater strength and unity" after these times of turmoil.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However six MIT students were sentenced to prison terms at this time and some former student leaders, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Albert" title="Michael Albert">
       Michael Albert
      </a>
      and George Katsiaficas, are still indignant about MIT's role in military research and its suppression of these protests.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Richard_Leacock" title="Richard Leacock">
       Richard Leacock
      </a>
      's film,
      <i>
       November Actions
      </i>
      , records some of these tumultuous events.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
      )
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Recent_history">
       Recent history
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Recent history">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Media_Lab.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2586" data-file-width="3879" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/MIT_Media_Lab.jpg/220px-MIT_Media_Lab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/MIT_Media_Lab.jpg/330px-MIT_Media_Lab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/MIT_Media_Lab.jpg/440px-MIT_Media_Lab.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Media_Lab.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/MIT_Media_Lab" title="MIT Media Lab">
         MIT Media Lab
        </a>
        houses researchers developing novel uses of computer technology. Shown here is the 1982 building, designed by
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I.M._Pei" title="I.M. Pei">
         I.M. Pei
        </a>
        , with an extension (right of photo) designed by
        <a href="/wiki/Fumihiko_Maki" title="Fumihiko Maki">
         Fumihiko Maki
        </a>
        opened in March 2010.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT has kept pace with and helped to advance the digital age. In addition to developing the predecessors to modern computing and
      <a href="/wiki/Computer_network" title="Computer network">
       networking
      </a>
      technologies,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
      students, staff, and faculty members at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_MAC" title="Project MAC">
       Project MAC
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Computer_Science_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Laboratory" title="MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory">
       Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Tech_Model_Railroad_Club" title="Tech Model Railroad Club">
       Tech Model Railroad Club
      </a>
      wrote some of the earliest interactive
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computer_video_game" title="Computer video game">
       computer video games
      </a>
      like
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Spacewar!" title="Spacewar!">
        Spacewar!
       </a>
      </i>
      and created much of modern
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hacker_(programmer_subculture)" title="Hacker (programmer subculture)">
       hacker
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Jargon_File" title="Jargon File">
       slang
      </a>
      and culture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Several major computer-related organizations have originated at MIT since the 1980s:
      <a href="/wiki/Richard_Stallman" title="Richard Stallman">
       Richard Stallman
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/GNU_Project" title="GNU Project">
       GNU Project
      </a>
      and the subsequent
      <a href="/wiki/Free_Software_Foundation" title="Free Software Foundation">
       Free Software Foundation
      </a>
      were founded in the mid-1980s at the AI Lab; the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Media_Lab" title="MIT Media Lab">
       MIT Media Lab
      </a>
      was founded in 1985 by
      <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Negroponte" title="Nicholas Negroponte">
       Nicholas Negroponte
      </a>
      and Jerome Wiesner to promote research into novel uses of computer technology;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web_Consortium" title="World Wide Web Consortium">
       World Wide Web Consortium
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Standards_organization" title="Standards organization">
       standards organization
      </a>
      was founded at the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Computer_Science_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Laboratory" title="MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory">
       Laboratory for Computer Science
      </a>
      in 1994 by
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">
       Tim Berners-Lee
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_OpenCourseWare" title="MIT OpenCourseWare">
       OpenCourseWare
      </a>
      project has made course materials for over 2,000 MIT classes available online free of charge since 2002;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/One_Laptop_per_Child" title="One Laptop per Child">
       One Laptop per Child
      </a>
      initiative to expand computer education and connectivity to children worldwide was launched in 2005.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT was named a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sea-grant_college" title="Sea-grant college">
       sea-grant college
      </a>
      in 1976 to support its programs in oceanography and marine sciences and was named a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space-grant_college" title="Space-grant college">
       space-grant college
      </a>
      in 1989 to support its aeronautics and astronautics programs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite diminishing government financial support over the past quarter century, MIT launched several successful
      <a href="/wiki/Fundraising" title="Fundraising">
       development campaigns
      </a>
      to significantly expand the campus: new dormitories and athletics buildings on west campus; the
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Tang_Center_for_Management_Education" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Tang Center for Management Education
      </a>
      ; several buildings in the northeast corner of campus supporting research into
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Koch_Biology_Building_.281994.29" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       biology
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Brain_and_Cognitive_Sciences_Building_.282006.29" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       brain and cognitive sciences
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Broad_Institute" title="Broad Institute">
       genomics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Whitehead_Institute" title="Whitehead Institute">
       biotechnology
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/David_H._Koch_Institute_for_Integrative_Cancer_Research#Building" title="David H. Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research">
       cancer research
      </a>
      ; and a number of new "backlot" buildings on Vassar Street including the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stata_Center" title="Stata Center">
       Stata Center
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Construction on campus in the 2000s included expansions of the Media Lab, the Sloan School's eastern campus, and graduate residences in the northwest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2006, President Hockfield launched the MIT Energy Research Council to investigate the interdisciplinary challenges posed by increasing
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_energy_resources_and_consumption" title="World energy resources and consumption">
       global energy consumption
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2001, inspired by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_source_movement" title="Open source movement">
       open source
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_access_movement" title="Open access movement">
       open access movements
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT launched
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_OpenCourseWare" title="MIT OpenCourseWare">
       OpenCourseWare
      </a>
      to make the lecture notes,
      <a href="/wiki/Problem_set" title="Problem set">
       problem sets
      </a>
      , syllabuses, exams, and lectures from the great majority of its courses available online for no charge, though without any formal accreditation for coursework completed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      While the cost of supporting and hosting the project is high,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      OCW expanded in 2005 to include other universities as a part of the OpenCourseWare Consortium, which currently includes more than 250 academic institutions with content available in at least six languages.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2011, MIT announced it would offer formal certification (but not credits or degrees) to online participants completing coursework in its "MITx" program, for a modest fee.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The "
      <a href="/wiki/EdX" title="EdX">
       edX
      </a>
      " online platform supporting MITx was initially developed in partnership with
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
       Harvard
      </a>
      and its analogous "Harvardx" initiative. The courseware platform is open source, and other universities have already joined and added their own course content.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Three days after the
      <a href="/wiki/Boston_Marathon_bombing" title="Boston Marathon bombing">
       Boston Marathon bombing
      </a>
      of April 2013,
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_Police_Department" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Department">
       MIT Police
      </a>
      patrol officer
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sean_Collier" title="Sean Collier">
       Sean Collier
      </a>
      was fatally shot by the suspects
      <a href="/wiki/Dzhokhar_Tsarnaev" title="Dzhokhar Tsarnaev">
       Dzhokhar
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tamerlan_Tsarnaev" title="Tamerlan Tsarnaev">
       Tamerlan Tsarnaev
      </a>
      , setting off a violent manhunt that shut down the campus and much of the Boston metropolitan area for a day.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      One week later, Collier's memorial service was attended by more than 10,000 people, in a ceremony hosted by the MIT community with thousands of police officers from the New England region and Canada.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bidgood_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bidgood-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Faviero_93-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Faviero-93">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On November 25, 2013, MIT announced the creation of the Collier Medal, to be awarded annually to "an individual or group that embodies the character and qualities that Officer Collier exhibited as a member of the MIT community and in all aspects of his life". The announcement further stated that "Future recipients of the award will include those whose contributions exceed the boundaries of their profession, those who have contributed to building bridges across the community, and those who consistently and selflessly perform acts of kindness".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITNCM_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITNCM-95">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITCM_96-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITCM-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rocheleau_97-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rocheleau-97">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Campus">
       Campus
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Campus">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG/220px-MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG/330px-MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG/440px-MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_East_Campus_aerial.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The central and eastern sections of MIT's campus as seen from above Massachusetts Avenue and the
        <a href="/wiki/Charles_River" title="Charles River">
         Charles River
        </a>
        . Left of center is the Great Dome overlooking Killian Court, with
        <a href="/wiki/Kendall_Square" title="Kendall Square">
         Kendall Square
        </a>
        to the upper right.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome,_Cambridge_MA.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg/220px-MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg/330px-MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg/440px-MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome%2C_Cambridge_MA.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Building_10_and_the_Great_Dome,_Cambridge_MA.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        MIT's Building 10 and Great Dome overlooking Killian Court
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT's 168-acre (68.0 ha) campus in the city of
      <a href="/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts" title="Cambridge, Massachusetts">
       Cambridge
      </a>
      spans approximately a mile along the north side of the
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_River" title="Charles River">
       Charles River
      </a>
      basin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campus_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Campus-6">
        [6]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The campus is divided roughly in half by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Cambridge)" title="Massachusetts Avenue (Cambridge)">
       Massachusetts Avenue
      </a>
      , with most dormitories and student life facilities to the west and most academic buildings to the east. The bridge closest to MIT is the
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Bridge" title="Harvard Bridge">
       Harvard Bridge
      </a>
      , which is known for being marked off in a
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_humorous_units_of_measurement" title="List of humorous units of measurement">
       non-standard unit of length
      </a>
      – the
      <a href="/wiki/Smoot" title="Smoot">
       smoot
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kendall/MIT_Station_(MBTA)" title="Kendall/MIT Station (MBTA)">
       Kendall
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Line_(MBTA)" title="Red Line (MBTA)">
       MBTA Red Line
      </a>
      station is located on the northeastern edge of the campus, in
      <a href="/wiki/Kendall_Square" title="Kendall Square">
       Kendall Square
      </a>
      . The Cambridge neighborhoods surrounding MIT are a mixture of high tech companies occupying both modern office and rehabilitated industrial buildings, as well as socio-economically diverse residential neighborhoods.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BO_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BO-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In early 2016, MIT presented its updated Kendall Square Initiative to the City of Cambridge, with plans for mixed-use educational, retail, residential, startup incubator, and office space in a dense high-rise
      <a href="/wiki/Transit-oriented_development" title="Transit-oriented development">
       transit-oriented development
      </a>
      plan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSI2016_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSI2016-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSI-home_103-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSI-home-103">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Museum" title="MIT Museum">
       MIT Museum
      </a>
      will eventually be moved immediately adjacent to a Kendall Square subway entrance, joining the
      <a href="/wiki/List_Visual_Arts_Center" title="List Visual Arts Center">
       List Visual Arts Center
      </a>
      on the eastern end of the campus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSI-home_103-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSI-home-103">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITN20140923_104-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITN20140923-104">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Each building at MIT
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Campus_organization" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       has a number
      </a>
      (possibly preceded by a
      <i>
       W
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       N
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       E
      </i>
      , or
      <i>
       NW
      </i>
      ) designation and most have a name as well. Typically, academic and office buildings are referred to primarily by number while residence halls are referred to by name. The organization of building numbers roughly corresponds to the order in which the buildings were built and their location relative (north, west, and east) to the original center cluster of Maclaurin buildings.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Numbering_system_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Numbering_system-105">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many of the buildings are connected above ground as well as through an extensive network of underground tunnels, providing protection from the Cambridge weather as well as a venue for
      <a href="/wiki/Roof_and_tunnel_hacking" title="Roof and tunnel hacking">
       roof and tunnel hacking
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Nuclear_Research_Reactor" title="MIT Nuclear Research Reactor">
       MIT's on-campus nuclear reactor
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
      is one of the most powerful university-based
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">
       nuclear reactors
      </a>
      in the United States. The prominence of the reactor's containment building in a densely populated area has been controversial,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but MIT maintains that it is well-secured.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1999
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">
       Bill Gates
      </a>
      donated US$20 million to MIT for the construction of a computer laboratory named the "William H. Gates Building", and designed by architect
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frank_O._Gehry" title="Frank O. Gehry">
       Frank O. Gehry
      </a>
      . While Microsoft had previously given financial support to the institution, this was the first personal donation received from Gates.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other notable campus facilities include a pressurized
      <a href="/wiki/Wind_tunnel" title="Wind tunnel">
       wind tunnel
      </a>
      and a
      <a href="/wiki/Ship_model_basin" title="Ship model basin">
       towing tank
      </a>
      for testing ship and ocean structure designs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT's campus-wide wireless network was completed in the fall of 2005 and consists of nearly 3,000 access points covering 9,400,000 square feet (870,000 m
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      ) of campus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2001, the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="United States Environmental Protection Agency">
       Environmental Protection Agency
      </a>
      sued MIT for violating the
      <a href="/wiki/Clean_Water_Act" title="Clean Water Act">
       Clean Water Act
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Clean_Air_Act_(United_States)" title="Clean Air Act (United States)">
       Clean Air Act
      </a>
      with regard to its
      <a href="/wiki/Hazardous_waste" title="Hazardous waste">
       hazardous waste
      </a>
      storage and disposal procedures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA_115-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA-115">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT settled the suit by paying a $155,000 fine and launching three environmental projects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In connection with capital campaigns to expand the campus, the Institute has also extensively renovated existing buildings to improve their energy efficiency. MIT has also taken steps to reduce its environmental impact by running
      <a href="/wiki/Alternative_fuel" title="Alternative fuel">
       alternative fuel
      </a>
      campus shuttles, subsidizing
      <a href="/wiki/CharlieCard" title="CharlieCard">
       public transportation passes
      </a>
      , and building a low-emission
      <a href="/wiki/Cogeneration" title="Cogeneration">
       cogeneration
      </a>
      plant that serves most of the campus electricity, heating, and cooling requirements.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_Police_Department" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Department">
       MIT Police
      </a>
      with state and local authorities, in the 2009-2011 period, have investigated reports of 12 forcible sex offenses, 6 robberies, 3 aggravated assaults, 164 burglaries, 1 case of arson, and 4 cases of motor vehicle theft on campus; affecting a community of around 22,000 students and employees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT also has substantial commercial real estate holdings in Cambridge, on which it pays property taxes. This includes Technology Square, parts of
      <a href="/wiki/Kendall_Square" title="Kendall Square">
       Kendall Square
      </a>
      , and many properties in
      <a href="/wiki/Cambridgeport,_Cambridge" title="Cambridgeport, Cambridge">
       Cambridgeport
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_4,_Cambridge" title="Area 4, Cambridge">
       Area 4
      </a>
      neighboring the educational buildings.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The land is held for investment purposes and potential long-term expansion.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
       Architecture
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Architecture">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wfm_stata_center.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="664" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Wfm_stata_center.jpg/220px-Wfm_stata_center.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Wfm_stata_center.jpg/330px-Wfm_stata_center.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Wfm_stata_center.jpg/440px-Wfm_stata_center.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wfm_stata_center.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stata_Center" title="Stata Center">
         Stata Center
        </a>
        houses
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CSAIL" title="CSAIL">
         CSAIL
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/MIT_Laboratory_for_Information_and_Decision_Systems" title="MIT Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems">
         LIDS
        </a>
        , and the
        <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Humanities,_Arts,_and_Social_Sciences" title="MIT School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences">
         Department of Linguistics and Philosophy
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Architecture_and_Planning" title="MIT School of Architecture and Planning">
       MIT's School of Architecture
      </a>
      , now the School of Architecture and Planning, was the first in the United States,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and it has a history of commissioning progressive buildings.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Starchitecture_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Starchitecture-121">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first buildings constructed on the Cambridge campus, completed in 1916, are sometimes called the "Maclaurin buildings" after Institute president
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Richard_Maclaurin" title="Richard Maclaurin">
       Richard Maclaurin
      </a>
      who oversaw their construction. Designed by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Welles_Bosworth" title="William Welles Bosworth">
       William Welles Bosworth
      </a>
      , these imposing buildings were built of
      <a href="/wiki/Reinforced_concrete" title="Reinforced concrete">
       reinforced concrete
      </a>
      , a first for a non-industrial – much less university – building in the US.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jarzombek1_123-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Jarzombek1-123">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Bosworth's design was influenced by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_Beautiful_Movement" title="City Beautiful Movement">
       City Beautiful Movement
      </a>
      of the early 1900s,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jarzombek1_123-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Jarzombek1-123">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and features the
      <a href="/wiki/Pantheon,_Rome" title="Pantheon, Rome">
       Pantheon
      </a>
      -esque Great Dome housing the Barker Engineering Library. The Great Dome overlooks Killian Court, where
      <a href="/wiki/Graduation" title="Graduation">
       graduation
      </a>
      ceremonies are held each year. The friezes of the limestone-clad buildings around Killian Court are engraved with the names of important scientists and philosophers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
       <a href="#cite_note-126">
        [a]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The spacious Building 7 atrium at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Cambridge)" title="Massachusetts Avenue (Cambridge)">
       77 Massachusetts Avenue
      </a>
      is regarded as the entrance to the
      <a href="/wiki/Infinite_Corridor" title="Infinite Corridor">
       Infinite Corridor
      </a>
      and the rest of the campus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BO_101-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-BO-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Alvar_Aalto" title="Alvar Aalto">
       Alvar Aalto
      </a>
      's Baker House (1947),
      <a href="/wiki/Eero_Saarinen" title="Eero Saarinen">
       Eero Saarinen
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Chapel" title="MIT Chapel">
       MIT Chapel
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kresge_Auditorium" title="Kresge Auditorium">
       Kresge Auditorium
      </a>
      (1955), and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I.M._Pei" title="I.M. Pei">
       I.M. Pei
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Green_Building_(MIT)" title="Green Building (MIT)">
       Green
      </a>
      , Dreyfus, Landau, and
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Media_Lab" title="MIT Media Lab">
       Wiesner
      </a>
      buildings represent high forms of post-war
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modernist_architecture" title="Modernist architecture">
       modernist architecture
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More recent buildings like
      <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gehry" title="Frank Gehry">
       Frank Gehry
      </a>
      's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stata_Center" title="Stata Center">
       Stata Center
      </a>
      (2004),
      <a href="/wiki/Steven_Holl" title="Steven Holl">
       Steven Holl
      </a>
      's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_MIT_undergraduate_dormitories#Simmons_Hall" title="List of MIT undergraduate dormitories">
       Simmons Hall
      </a>
      (2002),
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Correa" title="Charles Correa">
       Charles Correa
      </a>
      's Building 46 (2005), and
      <a href="/wiki/Fumihiko_Maki" title="Fumihiko Maki">
       Fumihiko Maki
      </a>
      's Media Lab Extension (2009) stand out among the Boston area's classical architecture and serve as examples of contemporary campus "starchitecture".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Starchitecture_121-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Starchitecture-121">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These buildings have not always been well received;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
       <a href="#cite_note-132">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in 2010,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Princeton_Review" title="The Princeton Review">
        The Princeton Review
       </a>
      </i>
      included MIT in a list of twenty schools whose campuses are "tiny, unsightly, or both".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        [132]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Housing">
       Housing
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Housing">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Housing_at_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Housing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Housing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Simmons_Hall,_MIT,_Cambridge,_Massachusetts.JPG">
