        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG/220px-Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG/330px-Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG/440px-Simmons_Hall%2C_MIT%2C_Cambridge%2C_Massachusetts.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Simmons_Hall,_MIT,_Cambridge,_Massachusetts.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_undergraduate_dormitories#Simmons_Hall_.28W79.29" title="List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology undergraduate dormitories">
         Simmons Hall
        </a>
        undergrad dormitory was completed in 2002
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Undergraduates are guaranteed four-year housing in one of MIT's 12
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_MIT_undergraduate_dormitories" title="List of MIT undergraduate dormitories">
       undergraduate dormitories
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Those living on campus can receive support and mentoring from live-in graduate student tutors, resident advisors, and faculty housemasters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
       <a href="#cite_note-135">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Because housing assignments are made based on the preferences of the students themselves, diverse social atmospheres can be sustained in different living groups; for example, according to the
      <i>
       Yale Daily News
      </i>
      staff's
      <i>
       The Insider's Guide to the Colleges, 2010
      </i>
      , "The split between East Campus and West Campus is a significant characteristic of MIT. East Campus has gained a reputation as a thriving counterculture."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT also has 5 dormitories for single graduate students and 2 apartment buildings on campus for married student families.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT has an active Greek and
      <a href="/wiki/Student_housing_cooperative" title="Student housing cooperative">
       co-op housing
      </a>
      system, including thirty-six
      <a href="/wiki/Fraternity" title="Fraternity">
       fraternities
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sorority" title="Sorority">
       sororities
      </a>
      , and independent living groups (FSILGs).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , 98% of all undergraduates lived in MIT-affiliated housing; 54% of the men participated in fraternities and 20% of the women were involved in sororities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDS_139-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CDS-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most FSILGs are located across the river in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Back_Bay" title="Back Bay">
       Back Bay
      </a>
      near where MIT was founded, and there is also a cluster of fraternities on MIT's West Campus that face the Charles River Basin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
       <a href="#cite_note-140">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the 1997 alcohol-related death of Scott Krueger, a new pledge at the
      <a href="/wiki/Phi_Gamma_Delta" title="Phi Gamma Delta">
       Phi Gamma Delta
      </a>
      fraternity, MIT required all freshmen to live in the dormitory system starting in 2002.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Because FSILGs had previously housed as many as 300 freshmen off-campus, the new policy could not be implemented until
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_MIT_undergraduate_dormitories#Simmons_Hall" title="List of MIT undergraduate dormitories">
       Simmons Hall
      </a>
      opened in that year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Organization_and_administration">
       Organization and administration
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Organization and administration">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Lobby_7.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3858" data-file-width="2549" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/MIT_Lobby_7.jpg/170px-MIT_Lobby_7.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/MIT_Lobby_7.jpg/255px-MIT_Lobby_7.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/MIT_Lobby_7.jpg/340px-MIT_Lobby_7.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Lobby_7.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Lobby 7 (at 77 Massachusetts Avenue) is regarded as the main entrance to campus
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT is chartered as a non-profit organization and is owned and governed by a privately appointed
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Board_of_trustees" title="Board of trustees">
       board of trustees
      </a>
      known as the MIT Corporation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The current board consists of 43 members elected to five-year terms,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
      25 life members who vote until their 75th birthday,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      3 elected officers (President, Treasurer, and Secretary),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 4
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ex_officio" title="Ex officio">
        ex officio
       </a>
      </i>
      members (the president of the alumni association, the
      <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Massachusetts" title="Governor of Massachusetts">
       Governor of Massachusetts
      </a>
      , the Massachusetts Secretary of Education, and the Chief Justice of the
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Supreme_Judicial_Court" title="Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court">
       Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
       <a href="#cite_note-148">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The board is chaired by
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Millard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Robert Millard (page does not exist)">
       Robert Millard
      </a>
      , a co-founder of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L-3_Communications_Holdings" title="L-3 Communications Holdings">
       L-3 Communications Holdings
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Corporation approves the budget, new programs, degrees and faculty appointments, and elects the President to serve as the chief executive officer of the university and preside over the Institute's faculty.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BO_101-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-BO-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
       <a href="#cite_note-151">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT's
      <a href="/wiki/Financial_endowment" title="Financial endowment">
       endowment
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Pension" title="Pension">
       other financial assets
      </a>
      are managed through a subsidiary called MIT Investment Management Company (MITIMCo).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Valued at $13.475 billion in 2015, MIT's endowment is the sixth-largest among American colleges and universities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NACUBO_3-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NACUBO-3">
        [3]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT has five schools (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Science" title="MIT School of Science">
       Science
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Engineering" title="MIT School of Engineering">
       Engineering
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Architecture_and_Planning" title="MIT School of Architecture and Planning">
       Architecture and Planning
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Sloan_School_of_Management" title="MIT Sloan School of Management">
       Management
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Humanities,_Arts,_and_Social_Sciences" title="MIT School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences">
       Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
      </a>
      ) and one college (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whitaker_College_of_Health_Sciences_and_Technology" title="Whitaker College of Health Sciences and Technology">
       Whitaker College of Health Sciences and Technology
      </a>
      ), but no schools of law or medicine.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schools_153-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Schools-153">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [b]
       </a>
      </sup>
      While faculty committees assert substantial control over many areas of MIT's curriculum, research, student life, and administrative affairs,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        [154]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the chair of each of MIT's 32 academic departments reports to the dean of that department's school, who in turn reports to the Provost under the President.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The current president is
      <a href="/wiki/L._Rafael_Reif" title="L. Rafael Reif">
       L. Rafael Reif
      </a>
      , who formerly served as provost under President
      <a href="/wiki/Susan_Hockfield" title="Susan Hockfield">
       Susan Hockfield
      </a>
      , the first woman to hold the post.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
       <a href="#cite_note-158">
        [156]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hockfield_159-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Hockfield-159">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Academics">
       Academics
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Academics">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      MIT is a large, highly residential, research university with a majority of enrollments in graduate and professional programs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carnegie_160-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Carnegie-160">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The university has been
      <a href="/wiki/Educational_accreditation" title="Educational accreditation">
       accredited
      </a>
      by the
      <a href="/wiki/New_England_Association_of_Schools_and_Colleges" title="New England Association of Schools and Colleges">
       New England Association of Schools and Colleges
      </a>
      since 1929.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
       <a href="#cite_note-161">
        [159]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT operates on a 4–1–4 academic calendar with the fall semester beginning after
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_Day_(United_States)" title="Labor Day (United States)">
       Labor Day
      </a>
      and ending in mid-December, a 4-week "Independent Activities Period" in the month of January, and the spring semester beginning in early February and ending in late May.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [161]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT students refer to both their majors and classes using numbers or acronyms alone.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Departments and their corresponding majors are numbered in the approximate order of their foundation; for example, Civil and Environmental Engineering is
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 1
      </span>
      , while Linguistics and Philosophy is
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 24
      </span>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Butcher_165-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Butcher-165">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Students majoring in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), the most popular department, collectively identify themselves as "Course 6". MIT students use a combination of the department's course number and the number assigned to the class to identify their subjects; the introductory calculus-based
      <a href="/wiki/Classical_mechanics" title="Classical mechanics">
       classical mechanics
      </a>
      course is simply "8.01" at MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [c]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Undergraduate_program">
       Undergraduate program
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Undergraduate program">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The four-year, full-time undergraduate program maintains a balance between professional majors and those in the arts and sciences, and has been dubbed "most selective" by
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report" title="U.S. News &amp; World Report">
        U.S. News
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_170-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-:0-170">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      admitting few transfer students
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carnegie_160-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Carnegie-160">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 8.0% of its applicants in the 2015 admissions cycle.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT offers 44 undergraduate degrees across its five schools.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2010–2011 academic year, 1,161 bachelor of science degrees (abbreviated "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scienti%C3%A6_Baccalaureus" title="Scientiæ Baccalaureus">
       SB
      </a>
      ") were granted, the only type of undergraduate degree MIT now awards.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Degrees_173-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Degrees-173">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2011 fall term, among students who had designated a major, the School of Engineering was the most popular division, enrolling 63% of students in its 19 degree programs, followed by the School of Science (29%), School of Humanities, Arts, &amp; Social Sciences (3.7%), Sloan School of Management (3.3%), and School of Architecture and Planning (2%).
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      The largest undergraduate degree programs were in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 6–2
      </span>
      ), Computer Science and Engineering (
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 6–3
      </span>
      ), Mechanical Engineering (
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 2
      </span>
      ), Physics (
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 8
      </span>
      ), and Mathematics (
      <span class="nowrap">
       Course 18
      </span>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Infinitecorridor.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Infinitecorridor.jpg/220px-Infinitecorridor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Infinitecorridor.jpg/330px-Infinitecorridor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Infinitecorridor.jpg/440px-Infinitecorridor.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Infinitecorridor.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Infinite_Corridor" title="Infinite Corridor">
         Infinite Corridor
        </a>
        is the primary passageway through campus
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      All undergraduates are required to complete a core curriculum called the General Institute Requirements (GIRs).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GIR_175-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GIR-175">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Science Requirement, generally completed during freshman year as prerequisites for classes in science and engineering majors, comprises two semesters of physics, two semesters of calculus, one semester of chemistry, and one semester of biology. There is a Laboratory Requirement, usually satisfied by an appropriate class in a course major. The Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (HASS) Requirement consists of eight semesters of classes in the humanities, arts, and social sciences, including at least one semester from each division as well as the courses required for a designated concentration in a HASS division. Under the Communication Requirement, two of the HASS classes, plus two of the classes taken in the designated major must be "communication-intensive",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CommReq_176-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CommReq-176">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including "substantial instruction and practice in oral presentation".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CommReqFac_177-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CommReqFac-177">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Finally, all students are required to complete a
      <a href="/wiki/Human_swimming" title="Human swimming">
       swimming
      </a>
      test;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      non-varsity athletes must also take four quarters of
      <a href="/wiki/Physical_education" title="Physical education">
       physical education
      </a>
      classes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GIR_175-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GIR-175">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Most classes rely on a combination of lectures, recitations led by associate professors or graduate students, weekly problem sets ("p-sets"), and periodic quizzes or tests. While the pace and difficulty of MIT coursework has been compared to "drinking from a fire hose",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
       <a href="#cite_note-180">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the freshmen retention rate at MIT is similar to other research universities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_170-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-:0-170">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The "pass/no-record" grading system relieves some pressure for first-year undergraduates. For each class taken in the fall term, freshmen transcripts will either report only that the class was passed, or otherwise not have any record of it. In the spring term, passing grades (A, B, C) appear on the transcript while non-passing grades are again not recorded.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Freshman_Year_181-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Freshman_Year-181">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (Grading had previously been "pass/no record" all freshman year, but was amended for the Class of 2006 to prevent students from
      <a href="/wiki/Gaming_the_system" title="Gaming the system">
       gaming the system
      </a>
      by completing required major classes in their freshman year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
       <a href="#cite_note-182">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ) Also, freshmen may choose to join alternative learning communities, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Experimental_Study_Group" title="Experimental Study Group">
       Experimental Study Group
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Concourse_Program_at_MIT" title="Concourse Program at MIT">
       Concourse
      </a>
      , or Terrascope.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Freshman_Year_181-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Freshman_Year-181">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1969,
      <a href="/wiki/Margaret_MacVicar" title="Margaret MacVicar">
       Margaret MacVicar
      </a>
      founded the
      <a href="/wiki/Undergraduate_Research_Opportunities_Program" title="Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program">
       Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program
      </a>
      (UROP) to enable undergraduates to collaborate directly with faculty members and researchers. Students join or initiate research projects ("UROPs") for academic credit, pay, or on a volunteer basis through postings on the UROP website or by contacting faculty members directly.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A substantial majority of undergraduates participate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
       <a href="#cite_note-185">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Students often become
      <a href="/wiki/Scientific_journal" title="Scientific journal">
       published
      </a>
      , file
      <a href="/wiki/Patent_application" title="Patent application">
       patent applications
      </a>
      , and/or launch
      <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">
       start-up companies
      </a>
      based upon their experience in UROPs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
       <a href="#cite_note-187">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1970, the then-Dean of Institute Relations, Benson R. Snyder, published
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Hidden_Curriculum" title="The Hidden Curriculum">
        The Hidden Curriculum
       </a>
       ,
      </i>
      arguing that education at MIT was often slighted in favor of following a set of unwritten expectations, and that graduating with good grades was more often the product of figuring out the system rather than a solid education. The successful student, according to Snyder, was the one who was able to discern which of the formal requirements were to be ignored in favor of which unstated norms. For example, organized student groups had compiled "
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Course_.22Bibles.22" title="History of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       course bibles
      </a>
      "—collections of problem-set and examination questions and answers for later students to use as references. This sort of gamesmanship, Snyder argued, hindered development of a creative intellect and contributed to student discontent and unrest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
       <a href="#cite_note-188">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:138px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Barker_Library.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="2592" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Barker_Library.jpg/136px-MIT_Barker_Library.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Barker_Library.jpg/204px-MIT_Barker_Library.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Barker_Library.jpg/272px-MIT_Barker_Library.jpg 2x" width="136"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Barker_Library.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Robert_Engman" title="Robert Engman">
         Robert Engman
        </a>
        's
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%B6bius_Strip" title="Möbius Strip">
         Möbius Strip
        </a>
        hanging from the crown of the Barker Engineering Library's reading room located inside the Great Dome. As of 2013, it has been removed.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Graduate_program">
       Graduate program
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Graduate program">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      MIT's graduate program has high coexistence with the undergraduate program, and many courses are taken by qualified students at both levels. MIT offers a comprehensive doctoral program with degrees in the humanities, social sciences, and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/STEM_fields" title="STEM fields">
       STEM fields
      </a>
      as well as professional degrees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carnegie_160-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Carnegie-160">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Institute offers graduate programs leading to academic degrees such as the Master of Science (MS), various Engineer's Degrees, Doctor of Philosophy (PhD), and Doctor of Science (ScD) and interdisciplinary graduate programs such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MD-PhD" title="MD-PhD">
       MD-PhD
      </a>
      (with
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Medical_School" title="Harvard Medical School">
       Harvard Medical School
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
       <a href="#cite_note-190">
        [187]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Admission to graduate programs is decentralized; applicants apply directly to the department or degree program. More than 90% of doctoral students are supported by fellowships, research assistantships (RAs), or teaching assistantships (TAs).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
       <a href="#cite_note-192">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT awarded 1,547 master's degrees and 609 doctoral degrees in the academic year 2010–11.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Degrees_173-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Degrees-173">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2011 fall term, the School of Engineering was the most popular academic division, enrolling 45.0% of graduate students, followed by the Sloan School of Management (19%), School of Science (16.9%), School of Architecture and Planning (9.2%), Whitaker College of Health Sciences (5.1%),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        [d]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (4.7%). The largest graduate degree programs were the Sloan
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MBA" title="MBA">
       MBA
      </a>
      , Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and Mechanical Engineering.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Rankings">
       Rankings
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Rankings">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="infobox" style="width: 22em">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="2" style="text-align: center; font-size: 125%">
        <a href="/wiki/College_and_university_rankings" title="College and university rankings">
         University rankings
        </a>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>

       </th>
      </tr>

       </th>
      </tr>

         </a>

       </td>
      </tr>

         </a>

        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rankings_QS_W_199-0">

       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
