          Times
         </a>
        </i>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rankings_THES_W_200-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Rankings_THES_W-200">
          [196]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </th>
       <td>
        5
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report" title="U.S. News &amp; World Report">
          U.S. News &amp; World Report
         </a>
        </i>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rankings_USNWR_W_201-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Rankings_USNWR_W-201">
          [197]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </th>
       <td>
        2
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      It also places among the top ten in many overall rankings of universities (see right) and rankings based on students'
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revealed_preferences" title="Revealed preferences">
       revealed preferences
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coughlan_204-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-coughlan-204">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For several years,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report" title="U.S. News &amp; World Report">
        U.S. News &amp; World Report
       </a>
      </i>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">
       QS World University Rankings
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">
       Academic Ranking of World Universities
      </a>
      have ranked MIT's School of Engineering first, as did the 1995
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_National_Research_Council" title="United States National Research Council">
       National Research Council
      </a>
      report.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1995_NRC_205-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-1995_NRC-205">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same lists, MIT's strongest showings apart from in engineering are in computer science, the natural sciences, business, economics, linguistics, mathematics, and, to a lesser extent, political science and philosophy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloomberg1_10-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-bloomberg1-10">
        [10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morgan1_11-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-morgan1-11">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclopedia1_12-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-encyclopedia1-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica1_13-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-britannica1-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2014,
      <a href="/wiki/Money_(magazine)" title="Money (magazine)">
       <i>
        Money
       </i>
       magazine
      </a>
      ranked MIT as third in the US "Best Colleges for Your Money", based on its assessment of "the most bang for your tuition buck", factoring in quality of education, affordability, and career outcomes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MoneyRank_207-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MoneyRank-207">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ,
      <i>
       Forbes
      </i>
      magazine rated MIT as the second "Most Entrepreneurial University", based on the percentage of alumni and students self-identifying as founders or business owners on
      <a href="/wiki/LinkedIn" title="LinkedIn">
       LinkedIn
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chen_208-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chen-208">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2015,
      <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">
       Brookings Fellow
      </a>
      Jonathan Rothwell issued a report "Beyond College Rankings", placing MIT as third in the US, with an estimated 45% value-added to mid-career salary.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Young_209-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Young-209">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Collaborations">
       Collaborations
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Collaborations">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2577" data-file-width="3870" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg/220px-MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg/330px-MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg/440px-MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Kresge_Auditorium.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Eero_Saarinen" title="Eero Saarinen">
         Eero Saarinen
        </a>
        's
        <a href="/wiki/Kresge_Auditorium" title="Kresge Auditorium">
         Kresge Auditorium
        </a>
        (1955) is a classic example of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mid-Century_modern" title="Mid-Century modern">
         post-war architecture
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The university historically pioneered research and training collaborations between academia, industry and government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1946, President Compton, Harvard Business School professor Georges Doriot, and Massachusetts Investor Trust chairman Merrill Grisswold founded
      <a href="/wiki/American_Research_and_Development_Corporation" title="American Research and Development Corporation">
       American Research and Development Corporation
      </a>
      , the first American
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venture-capital" title="Venture-capital">
       venture-capital
      </a>
      firm.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
       <a href="#cite_note-212">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
       <a href="#cite_note-213">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1948, Compton established the MIT Industrial Liaison Program.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout the late 1980s and early 1990s, American politicians and business leaders accused MIT and other universities of contributing to a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late_1980s_recession" title="Late 1980s recession">
       declining economy
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Technology_transfer" title="Technology transfer">
       transferring
      </a>
      taxpayer-funded research and technology to international – especially
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Japan" title="Economy of Japan">
       Japanese
      </a>
      – firms that were competing with struggling American businesses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
       <a href="#cite_note-215">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
       <a href="#cite_note-216">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On the other hand, MIT's extensive collaboration with the federal government on research projects has led to several MIT leaders serving as
      <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Science_Advisory_Committee" title="President's Science Advisory Committee">
       presidential scientific advisers
      </a>
      since 1940.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [e]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT established a Washington Office in 1991 to continue effective
      <a href="/wiki/Lobbying" title="Lobbying">
       lobbying
      </a>
      for research funding and national
      <a href="/wiki/Science_policy" title="Science policy">
       science policy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">
       U.S. Justice Department
      </a>
      began an investigation in 1989, and in 1991 filed an
      <a href="/wiki/Sherman_Antitrust_Act" title="Sherman Antitrust Act">
       antitrust suit
      </a>
      against MIT, the eight
      <a href="/wiki/Ivy_League" title="Ivy League">
       Ivy League
      </a>
      colleges, and eleven other institutions for allegedly engaging in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Price-fixing" title="Price-fixing">
       price-fixing
      </a>
      during their annual "Overlap Meetings", which were held to prevent bidding wars over promising prospective students from consuming funds for need-based scholarships.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
      While the Ivy League institutions
      <a href="/wiki/Consent_decree" title="Consent decree">
       settled
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT contested the charges, arguing that the practice was not anti-competitive because it ensured the availability of aid for the greatest number of students.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Overlap_224-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Overlap-224">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        [220]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT ultimately prevailed when the Justice Department dropped the case in 1994.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2183" data-file-width="3547" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg/220px-MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg/330px-MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg/440px-MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Walker_Memorial.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Walker Memorial is a monument to MIT's fourth president,
        <a href="/wiki/Francis_Amasa_Walker" title="Francis Amasa Walker">
         Francis Amasa Walker
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_2012-07-18.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1840" data-file-width="3264" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/MIT_2012-07-18.jpg/220px-MIT_2012-07-18.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/MIT_2012-07-18.jpg/330px-MIT_2012-07-18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/MIT_2012-07-18.jpg/440px-MIT_2012-07-18.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_2012-07-18.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        MIT main campus, seen from Vassar Street. The Great Dome is visible in the distance, and the Stata Center is at right.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT's proximity
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [f]
       </a>
      </sup>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
       Harvard University
      </a>
      ("the other school up the
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_River" title="Charles River">
       river
      </a>
      ") has led to a substantial number of research collaborations such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harvard-MIT_Division_of_Health_Sciences_and_Technology" title="Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology">
       Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Broad_Institute" title="Broad Institute">
       Broad Institute
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, students at the two schools can
      <a href="/wiki/Cross-registration" title="Cross-registration">
       cross-register
      </a>
      for credits toward their own school's degrees without any additional fees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A cross-registration program between MIT and
      <a href="/wiki/Wellesley_College" title="Wellesley College">
       Wellesley College
      </a>
      has also existed since 1969, and in 2002 the
      <a href="/wiki/Cambridge%E2%80%93MIT_Institute" title="Cambridge–MIT Institute">
       Cambridge–MIT Institute
      </a>
      launched an undergraduate exchange program between MIT and the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">
       University of Cambridge
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT has more modest cross-registration programs with
      <a href="/wiki/Boston_University" title="Boston University">
       Boston University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Brandeis_University" title="Brandeis University">
       Brandeis University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tufts_University" title="Tufts University">
       Tufts University
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Massachusetts_College_of_Art" title="Massachusetts College of Art">
       Massachusetts College of Art
      </a>
      , and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School_of_the_Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Boston" title="School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston">
       School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT maintains substantial research and faculty ties with independent research organizations in the Boston area, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stark_Draper_Laboratory" title="Charles Stark Draper Laboratory">
       Charles Stark Draper Laboratory
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Whitehead_Institute" title="Whitehead Institute">
       Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Woods_Hole_Oceanographic_Institution" title="Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution">
       Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution
      </a>
      . Ongoing international research and educational collaborations include the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore-MIT_Alliance" title="Singapore-MIT Alliance">
       Singapore-MIT Alliance
      </a>
      , MIT-
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Politecnico_di_Milano" title="Politecnico di Milano">
       Politecnico di Milano
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT-
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zaragoza" title="University of Zaragoza">
       Zaragoza
      </a>
      International Logistics Program, and projects in other countries through the MIT International Science and Technology Initiatives (MISTI) program.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdPart_229-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdPart-229">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The mass-market magazine
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technology_Review" title="Technology Review">
        Technology Review
       </a>
      </i>
      is published by MIT through a subsidiary company, as is a special edition that also serves as an
      <a href="/wiki/Alumni_magazine" title="Alumni magazine">
       alumni magazine
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Press" title="MIT Press">
       MIT Press
      </a>
      is a major
      <a href="/wiki/University_press" title="University press">
       university press
      </a>
      , publishing over 200 books and 30 journals annually, emphasizing science and technology as well as arts, architecture, new media, current events, and social issues.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
       <a href="#cite_note-234">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Libraries.2C_collections_and_museums">
       Libraries, collections and museums
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Libraries, collections and museums">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_Libraries" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology Libraries">
       Massachusetts Institute of Technology Libraries
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Campus_of_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology#Artwork" title="Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology § Artwork
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The MIT library system consists of five subject libraries: Barker (Engineering), Dewey (Economics), Hayden (Humanities and Science), Lewis (Music), and Rotch (Arts and Architecture). There are also various specialized libraries and archives. The libraries contain more than 2.9 million printed volumes, 2.4 million microforms, 49,000 print or electronic journal subscriptions, and 670 reference databases. The past decade has seen a trend of increased focus on digital over print resources in the libraries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Notable collections include the Lewis Music Library with an emphasis on 20th and 21st-century music and electronic music,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/List_Visual_Arts_Center" title="List Visual Arts Center">
       List Visual Arts Center
      </a>
      's rotating exhibitions of contemporary art,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
       <a href="#cite_note-237">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the Compton Gallery's cross-disciplinary exhibitions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT allocates a percentage of the budget for all new construction and renovation to commission and support its extensive public art and outdoor sculpture collection.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Museum" title="MIT Museum">
       MIT Museum
      </a>
      was founded in 1971 and collects, preserves, and exhibits artifacts significant to the culture and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_MIT" title="History of MIT">
       history of MIT
      </a>
      . The museum now engages in significant educational outreach programs for the general public, including the annual
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Museum#Cambridge_Science_Festival" title="MIT Museum">
       Cambridge Science Festival
      </a>
      , the first celebration of this kind in the United States. Since 2005, its official mission has been, "to engage the wider community with MIT's science, technology and other areas of scholarship in ways that will best serve the nation and the world in the 21st century".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITMuseum_241-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITMuseum-241">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Research">
       Research
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Research">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      MIT was elected to the
      <a href="/wiki/Association_of_American_Universities" title="Association of American Universities">
       Association of American Universities
      </a>
      in 1934 and remains a research university with a very high level of research activity;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AAU_46-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AAU-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carnegie_160-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Carnegie-160">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      research expenditures totaled $718.2 million in 2009.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Research_242-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Research-242">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The federal government was the largest source of sponsored research, with the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services" title="Department of Health and Human Services">
       Department of Health and Human Services
      </a>
      granting $255.9 million,
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">
       Department of Defense
      </a>
      $97.5 million,
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Energy" title="United States Department of Energy">
       Department of Energy
      </a>
      $65.8 million,
      <a href="/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">
       National Science Foundation
      </a>
      $61.4 million, and
      <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">
       NASA
      </a>
      $27.4 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Research_242-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Research-242">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT employs approximately 1300 researchers in addition to faculty.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITFac_243-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITFac-243">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2011, MIT faculty and researchers disclosed 632 inventions, were issued 153 patents, earned $85.4 million in cash income, and received $69.6 million in royalties.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Through programs like the Deshpande Center, MIT faculty leverage their research and discoveries into multi-million-dollar commercial ventures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
       <a href="#cite_note-245">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
      In electronics,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magnetic_core_memory" title="Magnetic core memory">
       magnetic core memory
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">
       radar
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Single_electron_transistor" title="Single electron transistor">
       single electron transistors
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inertial_guidance" title="Inertial guidance">
       inertial guidance
      </a>
      controls were invented or substantially developed by MIT researchers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RLE_History_247-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RLE_History-247">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Harold_Eugene_Edgerton" title="Harold Eugene Edgerton">
       Harold Eugene Edgerton
      </a>
      was a pioneer in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_speed_photography" title="High speed photography">
       high speed photography
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sonar" title="Sonar">
       sonar
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
       <a href="#cite_note-248">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
       <a href="#cite_note-249">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Claude_E._Shannon" title="Claude E. Shannon">
       Claude E. Shannon
      </a>
      developed much of modern
      <a href="/wiki/Information_theory" title="Information theory">
       information theory
      </a>
      and discovered the application of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boolean_logic" title="Boolean logic">
       Boolean logic
      </a>
      to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digital_circuit" title="Digital circuit">
       digital circuit
      </a>
      design theory.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
       <a href="#cite_note-250">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the domain of computer science, MIT faculty and researchers made fundamental contributions to
      <a href="/wiki/Norbert_Wiener" title="Norbert Wiener">
       cybernetics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marvin_Minsky" title="Marvin Minsky">
       artificial intelligence
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Weizenbaum" title="Joseph Weizenbaum">
       computer languages
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Winston" title="Patrick Winston">
       machine learning
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Brooks" title="Rodney Brooks">
       robotics
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ronald_Rivest" title="Ronald Rivest">
       cryptography
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RLE_History_247-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RLE_History-247">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
      At least nine
      <a href="/wiki/Turing_Award" title="Turing Award">
       Turing Award
      </a>
      laureates and seven recipients of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Draper_Prize" title="Draper Prize">
       Draper Prize
      </a>
      in engineering have been or are currently associated with MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TuringAward_252-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TuringAward-252">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Current and previous physics faculty have won eight
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">
       Nobel Prizes
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IR_Nobel_254-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IR_Nobel-254">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      four
      <a href="/wiki/Dirac_Medal#Dirac_Medal_of_the_ICTP" title="Dirac Medal">
       Dirac Medals
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and three
      <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize" title="Wolf Prize">
       Wolf Prizes
      </a>
      predominantly for their contributions to subatomic and quantum theory.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Members of the chemistry department have been awarded three
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">
       Nobel Prizes
      </a>
      and one Wolf Prize for the discovery of novel syntheses and methods.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IR_Nobel_254-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IR_Nobel-254">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT biologists have been awarded six
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Medicine">
       Nobel Prizes
      </a>
      for their contributions to genetics, immunology, oncology, and molecular biology.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IR_Nobel_254-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-IR_Nobel-254">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Professor
      <a href="/wiki/Eric_Lander" title="Eric Lander">
       Eric Lander
      </a>
      was one of the principal leaders of the
      <a href="/wiki/Human_Genome_Project" title="Human Genome Project">
       Human Genome Project
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
       <a href="#cite_note-257">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
       <a href="#cite_note-258">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Positronium" title="Positronium">
       Positronium
      </a>
      atoms,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      synthetic
      <a href="/wiki/Penicillin" title="Penicillin">
       penicillin
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Julius_Rebek" title="Julius Rebek">
       synthetic self-replicating molecules
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the genetic bases for
      <a href="/wiki/Amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis" title="Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis">
       Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
      </a>
      (also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease) and
      <a href="/wiki/Huntington%27s_disease" title="Huntington's disease">
       Huntington's disease
      </a>
      were first discovered at MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MIT_Firsts_262-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MIT_Firsts-262">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Lettvin" title="Jerome Lettvin">
       Jerome Lettvin
      </a>
      transformed the study of cognitive science with his paper "What the frog's eye tells the frog's brain".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
       <a href="#cite_note-263">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the domain of humanities, arts, and social sciences, MIT economists have been awarded five
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Economics" title="Nobel Prize in Economics">
       Nobel Prizes
      </a>
      and nine
      <a href="/wiki/John_Bates_Clark_Medal" title="John Bates Clark Medal">
       John Bates Clark Medals
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IR_Nobel_254-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-IR_Nobel-254">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Linguists
      <a href="/wiki/Noam_Chomsky" title="Noam Chomsky">
       Noam Chomsky
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Morris_Halle" title="Morris Halle">
       Morris Halle
      </a>
      authored seminal texts on
      <a href="/wiki/Generative_grammar" title="Generative grammar">
       generative grammar
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">
       phonology
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Media_Lab" title="MIT Media Lab">
       MIT Media Lab
      </a>
      , founded in 1985 within the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_School_of_Architecture_and_Planning" title="MIT School of Architecture and Planning">
       School of Architecture and Planning
      </a>
      and known for its unconventional research,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      has been home to influential researchers such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constructivism_(learning_theory)" title="Constructivism (learning theory)">
       constructivist
      </a>
      educator and
      <a href="/wiki/Logo_(programming_language)" title="Logo (programming language)">
       Logo
      </a>
      creator
      <a href="/wiki/Seymour_Papert" title="Seymour Papert">
       Seymour Papert
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Spanning many of the above fields,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MacArthur_Fellowship" title="MacArthur Fellowship">
       MacArthur Fellowships
      </a>
      (the so-called "Genius Grants") have been awarded to 38 people associated with MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacArthur_270-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MacArthur-270">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Four
      <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize" title="Pulitzer Prize">
       Pulitzer Prize
      </a>
      –winning writers currently work at or have retired from MIT.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pulitzer_271-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pulitzer-271">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Four current or former faculty are members of the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Academy_of_Arts_and_Letters" title="American Academy of Arts and Letters">
       American Academy of Arts and Letters
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AcademyArts_272-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AcademyArts-272">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Allegations of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Research_misconduct" title="Research misconduct">
       research misconduct
      </a>
      or improprieties have received substantial press coverage. Professor
      <a href="/wiki/David_Baltimore" title="David Baltimore">
       David Baltimore
      </a>
      , a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_for_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine">
       Nobel Laureate
      </a>
      , became embroiled in a misconduct investigation starting in 1986 that led to Congressional hearings in 1991.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baltimore_273-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Baltimore-273">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Winner_274-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Winner-274">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Professor
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ted_Postol" title="Ted Postol">
       Ted Postol
      </a>
      has accused the MIT administration since 2000 of attempting to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whitewash_(censorship)" title="Whitewash (censorship)">
       whitewash
      </a>
      potential research misconduct at the Lincoln Lab facility involving a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_defense" title="Ballistic missile defense">
       ballistic missile defense
      </a>
      test, though a final investigation into the matter has not been completed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Associate Professor
      <a href="/wiki/Luk_Van_Parijs" title="Luk Van Parijs">
       Luk Van Parijs
      </a>
      was dismissed in 2005 following allegations of scientific misconduct and found guilty of the same by the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Office_of_Research_Integrity" title="United States Office of Research Integrity">
       United States Office of Research Integrity
      </a>
      in 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
       <a href="#cite_note-278">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Researchers developed a system to convert MRI scans into 3D printed physical models.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Discoveries_and_innovation">
       Discoveries and innovation
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Discoveries and innovation">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote selfref" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University#Discoveries_and_innovation" title="Stanford University">
       Stanford discoveries and innovation
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#Discoveries_and_innovation" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
       Carnegie Mellon discoveries and innovation
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Illinois_at_Urbana-Champaign#Discoveries_and_innovation" title="University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign">
       Illinois discoveries and innovation
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley#Discoveries_and_innovation" title="University of California, Berkeley">
       Cal Berkeley discoveries and innovation
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Heckert_GNU_white.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="523" data-file-width="535" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/22/Heckert_GNU_white.svg/170px-Heckert_GNU_white.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/22/Heckert_GNU_white.svg/255px-Heckert_GNU_white.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/22/Heckert_GNU_white.svg/340px-Heckert_GNU_white.svg.png 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Heckert_GNU_white.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GNU_project" title="GNU project">
         GNU project
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Free_software_movement" title="Free software movement">
         free software movement
        </a>
        originated at MIT
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web_Consortium" title="World Wide Web Consortium">
        World Wide Web Consortium
       </a>
       - Founded in 1994 by
       <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">
        Tim Berners-Lee
       </a>
       , (W3C) is the main international
       <a href="/wiki/Standards_organization" title="Standards organization">
        standards organization
       </a>
       for the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">
        World Wide Web
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-consortium_280-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-consortium-280">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/VisiCalc" title="VisiCalc">
        VisiCalc
       </a>
       - was the first
       <a href="/wiki/Spreadsheet" title="Spreadsheet">
        spreadsheet
       </a>
       computer program for
       <a href="/wiki/Personal_computer" title="Personal computer">
        personal computers
       </a>
       , originally released for the
       <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">
        Apple II
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/VisiCorp" title="VisiCorp">
        VisiCorp
       </a>
       . MIT alum
       <a href="/wiki/Dan_Bricklin" title="Dan Bricklin">
        Dan Bricklin
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bob_Frankston" title="Bob Frankston">
        Bob Frankston
       </a>
       rented time sharing at night on an MIT mainframe computer (that cost $1/hr for use).
       <a href="/wiki/Lotus_1-2-3" title="Lotus 1-2-3">
        Lotus 1-2-3
       </a>
       killed it and
       <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Excel" title="Microsoft Excel">
        Microsoft Excel
       </a>
       rains supreme today.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Akamai_Technologies" title="Akamai Technologies">
        Akamai Technologies
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Lewin" title="Daniel Lewin">
        Daniel Lewin
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tom_Leighton" title="Tom Leighton">
        Tom Leighton
       </a>
       discovered and developed a faster
       <a href="/wiki/Content_delivery_network" title="Content delivery network">
        content delivery network
       </a>
       and is one of the world's largest
       <a href="/wiki/Distributed_computing" title="Distributed computing">
        distributed computing
       </a>
       platforms, responsible for serving between 15 and 30 percent of all web traffic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-figures_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-figures-281">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Cryptography" title="Cryptography">
        Cryptography
       </a>
       - MIT professors
       <a href="/wiki/Ron_Rivest" title="Ron Rivest">
        Ron Rivest
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shamir" title="Adi Shamir">
        Adi Shamir
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Adleman" title="Leonard Adleman">
        Leonard Adleman
       </a>
       developed one of the first practical
       <a href="/wiki/Public-key_cryptography" title="Public-key cryptography">
        public-key cryptosystems
       </a>
       and started a company
       <a href="/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem)" title="RSA (cryptosystem)">
        RSA (cryptosystem)
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Flight_recorder" title="Flight recorder">
        Flight recorder (black box)
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stark_Draper" title="Charles Stark Draper">
        Charles Stark Draper
       </a>
       developed the black box at
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stark_Draper_Laboratory" title="Charles Stark Draper Laboratory">
        MIT's Instrumentation Laboratory
       </a>
       . That lab later made the
       <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">
        Apollo Moon landings
       </a>
       possible through the
       <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Guidance_Computer" title="Apollo Guidance Computer">
        Apollo Guidance Computer
       </a>
       it designed for
       <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">
        NASA
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/David_Baltimore#Reverse_transcriptase" title="David Baltimore">
        Reverse transcription
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/David_Baltimore" title="David Baltimore">
        David Baltimore
       </a>
       independently isolated, in 1970 at MIT, two RNA tumour viruses:
       <a href="/wiki/Murine_leukemia_virus" title="Murine leukemia virus">
        R-MLV
       </a>
       and again
       <a href="/wiki/Rous_sarcoma_virus" title="Rous sarcoma virus">
        RSV
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid4316300_282-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pmid4316300-282">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Oncogene" title="Oncogene">
        Oncogene
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Weinberg" title="Robert Weinberg">
        Robert Weinberg
       </a>
       discovered genetic basis of human cancer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery#Commercial_production" title="Lithium-ion battery">
        Lithium-ion battery efficiencies
       </a>
       - Yet-Ming Chiang and his group at MIT showed a substantial improvement in the performance of lithium batteries by boosting the material's conductivity by
       <a href="/wiki/Doping_(semiconductor)" title="Doping (semiconductor)">
        doping
       </a>
       it
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">
        aluminium
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Niobium" title="Niobium">
        niobium
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Zirconium" title="Zirconium">
        zirconium
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/MIT_OpenCourseWare" title="MIT OpenCourseWare">
        MIT OpenCourseWare
       </a>
       - The
       <a href="/wiki/OpenCourseWare" title="OpenCourseWare">
        OpenCourseWare
       </a>
       movement started in 1999 when the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_T%C3%BCbingen" title="University of Tübingen">
        University of Tübingen
       </a>
       in Germany published videos of
       <a href="/wiki/Lecture" title="Lecture">
        lectures
       </a>
       online for its
       <i>
        timms
       </i>
       initiative (Tübinger Internet Multimedia Server).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tub99_285-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tub99-285">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The OCW movement only took off, however, with the launch of MIT OpenCourseWare and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Open_Learning_Initiative&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Open Learning Initiative (page does not exist)">
        Open Learning Initiative
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
        Carnegie Mellon University
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in October 2002. The movement was soon reinforced by the launch of similar projects at
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yale" title="Yale">
        Yale
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Utah_State_University" title="Utah State University">
        Utah State University
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Michigan" title="University of Michigan">
        University of Michigan
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_California_Berkeley" title="University of California Berkeley">
        University of California Berkeley
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Radar_in_World_War_II" title="Radar in World War II">
        Radar
       </a>
       - Developed at MIT's
       <a href="/wiki/Radiation_Laboratory_(MIT)" title="Radiation Laboratory (MIT)">
        Radiation Laboratory
       </a>
       during
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)" title="Lisp (programming language)">
        Lisp (programming language)
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist)" title="John McCarthy (computer scientist)">
        John McCarthy
       </a>
       invented lisp in 1958 while he was at (MIT). McCarthy published its design in a paper in
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Communications_of_the_ACM" title="Communications of the ACM">
         Communications of the ACM
        </a>
       </i>
       in 1960, entitled "Recursive Functions of Symbolic Expressions and Their Computation by Machine, Part I".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCCARTHY_287-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCCARTHY-287">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Sketchpad" title="Sketchpad">
        SKETCHPAD
       </a>
       - invented by
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Sutherland" title="Ivan Sutherland">
        Ivan Sutherland
       </a>
       as his thesis for his PhD at MIT. It pioneered the way for
       <a href="/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction" title="Human–computer interaction">
        human–computer interaction
       </a>
       (HCI).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SearsJacko2007_288-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SearsJacko2007-288">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Sketchpad is considered to be the ancestor of modern
       <a href="/wiki/Computer-aided_design" title="Computer-aided design">
        computer-aided design
       </a>
       (CAD) programs as well as a major breakthrough in the development of
       <a href="/wiki/Computer_graphics" title="Computer graphics">
        computer graphics
       </a>
       in general.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_MAC" title="Project MAC">
        Project MAC
       </a>
       - groundbreaking research in
       <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">
        operating systems
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">
        artificial intelligence
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_computation" title="Theory of computation">
        theory of computation
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/DARPA" title="DARPA">
        DARPA
       </a>
       funded project.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Emacs" title="Emacs">
        Emacs (text editor)
       </a>
       - development began during the 1970s at the
       <a href="/wiki/MIT_Computer_Science_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Laboratory" title="MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory">
        MIT AI Lab
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/GNU_Project" title="GNU Project">
        GNU Project
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Richard_Stallman" title="Richard Stallman">
        Richard Stallman
       </a>
       formally founded the
       <a href="/wiki/Free_software_movement" title="Free software movement">
        free software movement
       </a>
       in 1983 by launching the
       <a href="/wiki/GNU_Project" title="GNU Project">
        GNU Project
       </a>
       at MIT.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Traditions_and_student_activities">
       Traditions and student activities
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Traditions and student activities">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Traditions_and_student_activities_at_MIT" title="Traditions and student activities at MIT">
       Traditions and student activities at MIT
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_class_ring" title="MIT class ring">
       MIT class ring
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_in_popular_culture" title="MIT in popular culture">
       MIT in popular culture
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The faculty and student body place a high value on
      <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">
       meritocracy
      </a>
      and on technical proficiency.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
       <a href="#cite_note-292">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT has never awarded an
      <a href="/wiki/Honorary_degree" title="Honorary degree">
       honorary degree
      </a>
      , nor does it award
      <a href="/wiki/Athletic_scholarship" title="Athletic scholarship">
       athletic scholarships
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ad_eundem_degree" title="Ad eundem degree">
       ad eundem degrees
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Latin_honors" title="Latin honors">
       Latin honors
      </a>
      upon graduation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, MIT has twice awarded honorary professorships: to
      <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">
       Winston Churchill
      </a>
      in 1949 and
      <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">
       Salman Rushdie
      </a>
      in 1993.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Many
      <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/upperclassman" title="wikt:upperclassman">
       upperclass
      </a>
      students and alumni wear a large, heavy, distinctive
      <a href="/wiki/Class_ring" title="Class ring">
       class ring
      </a>
      known as the "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brass_Rat" title="Brass Rat">
       Brass Rat
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brass_Rat_296-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Brass_Rat-296">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrassRat2013_297-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BrassRat2013-297">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Originally created in 1929, the ring's official name is the "Standard Technology Ring."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The undergraduate ring design (a separate graduate student version exists as well) varies slightly from year to year to reflect the unique character of the MIT experience for that class, but always features a three-piece design, with the MIT seal and the class year each appearing on a separate face, flanking a large rectangular bezel bearing an image of a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Beaver" title="American Beaver">
       beaver
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brass_Rat_296-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Brass_Rat-296">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Initialism" title="Initialism">
       initialism
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IHTFP" title="IHTFP">
       IHTFP
      </a>
      , representing the informal school motto "I Hate This Fucking Place" and jocularly euphemized as "I Have Truly Found Paradise," "Institute Has The Finest Professors," "It's Hard to Fondle Penguins," and other variations, has occasionally been featured on the ring given its historical prominence in student culture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
       <a href="#cite_note-299">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Activities">
       Activities
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Activities">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Traditions_and_student_activities_at_MIT" title="Traditions and student activities at MIT">
       Traditions and student activities at MIT
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Hacks_at_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Hacks at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Hacks at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg/220px-Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg/330px-Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg/440px-Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Huntbeginsinlobby7.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The start of the
        <a href="/wiki/MIT_Mystery_Hunt" title="MIT Mystery Hunt">
         MIT Mystery Hunt
        </a>
        in 2007
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT has over 500 recognized student activity groups,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
       <a href="#cite_note-300">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including a
      <a href="/wiki/WMBR" title="WMBR">
       campus radio station
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Tech_(newspaper)" title="The Tech (newspaper)">
        The Tech
       </a>
      </i>
      student newspaper, an annual
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_$100K_Entrepreneurship_Competition" title="MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Competition">
       entrepreneurship competition
      </a>
      , and weekly screenings of popular films by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Student_life_and_culture_at_MIT#Lecture_Series_Committee" title="Student life and culture at MIT">
       Lecture Series Committee
      </a>
      . Less traditional activities include the "world's largest open-shelf
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Science_Fiction_Society" title="MIT Science Fiction Society">
       collection of science fiction
      </a>
      " in English, a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TMRC" title="TMRC">
       model railroad club
      </a>
      , and a vibrant
      <a href="/wiki/Tech_Squares" title="Tech Squares">
       folk dance
      </a>
      scene. Students, faculty, and staff are involved in over 50 educational outreach and public service programs through the
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Museum" title="MIT Museum">
       MIT Museum
      </a>
      , Edgerton Center, and MIT Public Service Center.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
       <a href="#cite_note-301">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Student_life_and_culture_at_MIT#Independent_Activities_Period" title="Student life and culture at MIT">
       Independent Activities Period
      </a>
      is a four-week-long "term" offering hundreds of optional classes, lectures, demonstrations, and other activities throughout the month of January between the Fall and Spring semesters. Some of the most popular recurring IAP activities are the 6.270, 6.370, and MasLab
      <a href="/wiki/Traditions_and_student_activities_at_MIT#Competitions" title="Traditions and student activities at MIT">
       competitions
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Discover_302-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Discover-302">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the annual
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Mystery_Hunt" title="MIT Mystery Hunt">
       "mystery hunt"
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Globe_303-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Globe-303">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Student_life_and_culture_at_MIT#Charm_School" title="Student life and culture at MIT">
       Charm School
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CharmSchool_304-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CharmSchool-304">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
       <a href="#cite_note-305">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More than 250 students pursue externships annually at companies in the US and abroad.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
       <a href="#cite_note-307">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Many MIT students also engage in "hacking", which encompasses both the
      <a href="/wiki/Roof_and_tunnel_hacking" title="Roof and tunnel hacking">
       physical exploration of areas
      </a>
      that are generally off-limits (such as rooftops and steam tunnels), as well as
      <a href="/wiki/Hacks_at_the_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Hacks at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       elaborate practical jokes
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        [303]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Recent high-profile hacks have included the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caltech%27s_rival" title="Caltech's rival">
       abduction of Caltech's cannon
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
      reconstructing a
      <a href="/wiki/Wright_Flyer" title="Wright Flyer">
       Wright Flyer
      </a>
      atop the Great Dome,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
       <a href="#cite_note-311">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and adorning the
      <a href="/wiki/John_Harvard_(clergyman)" title="John Harvard (clergyman)">
       John Harvard
      </a>
      statue with the
      <a href="/wiki/Master_Chief_(Halo)" title="Master Chief (Halo)">
       Master Chief's Mjölnir Helmet
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
       <a href="#cite_note-312">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Athletics">
       Athletics
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Athletics">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/MIT_Engineers" title="MIT Engineers">
       MIT Engineers
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Z_Center.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2585" data-file-width="3871" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/MIT_Z_Center.jpg/220px-MIT_Z_Center.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/MIT_Z_Center.jpg/330px-MIT_Z_Center.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/MIT_Z_Center.jpg/440px-MIT_Z_Center.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MIT_Z_Center.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zesiger_sports_and_fitness_center" title="Zesiger sports and fitness center">
         Zesiger sports and fitness center
        </a>
        houses a two-story fitness center as well as swimming and diving pools
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      MIT sponsors 31 varsity sports and has one of the three broadest NCAA Division III athletic programs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
       <a href="#cite_note-313">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Athletics_314-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Athletics-314">
        [308]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT participates in the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association" title="National Collegiate Athletic Association">
       NCAA's
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA)" title="Division III (NCAA)">
       Division III
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/New_England_Women%27s_and_Men%27s_Athletic_Conference" title="New England Women's and Men's Athletic Conference">
       New England Women's and Men's Athletic Conference
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/New_England_Football_Conference" title="New England Football Conference">
       New England Football Conference
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pilgrim_League" title="Pilgrim League">
       Pilgrim League
      </a>
      for men's lacrosse,
      <a href="/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association" title="National Collegiate Athletic Association">
       NCAA's
      </a>
      Division I
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Association_of_Women%27s_Rowing_Colleges" title="Eastern Association of Women's Rowing Colleges">
       Eastern Association of Women's Rowing Colleges (EAWRC)
      </a>
      for women's crew, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Collegiate_Water_Polo_Association" title="Collegiate Water Polo Association">
       Collegiate Water Polo Association (CWPA)
      </a>
      for Men's Water Polo. Men's crew competes outside the NCAA in the
      <a href="/wiki/College_rowing_(United_States)#Eastern_Association_of_Rowing_Colleges" title="College rowing (United States)">
       Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges (EARC)
      </a>
      . In April 2009, budget cuts led to MIT eliminating eight of its 41 sports, including the mixed men's and women's teams in alpine skiing and pistol; separate teams for men and women in ice hockey and gymnastics; and men's programs in golf and wrestling.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
       <a href="#cite_note-316">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="People">
       People
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: People">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Students">
       Students
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Students">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; float:right; font-size:85%; margin-left:2em;">
      <caption>
       <i>
        Demographics of MIT student body
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-International_Students_317-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-International_Students-317">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </caption>
      <tr>
       <th>
       </th>
       <th>
        Undergraduate
       </th>
       <th>
        Graduate
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_American" title="White American">
         White American
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        34%
       </td>
       <td>
        40.8%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">
         Asian American
        </a>
       </th>

       </td>
       <td>
        9.4%
       </td>
      </tr>

        <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">
         Hispanic American
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
