       </td>
       <td>
        3.3%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">
         African American
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        10%
       </td>
       <td>
        2.1%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">
         Native American
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        1.0%
       </td>
       <td>
        0.4%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
        <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">
         Other/International
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        8%
       </td>
       <td>
        44.0%
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      MIT enrolled 4,384 undergraduates and 6,510 graduate students in 2011–2012.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Women constituted 45 percent of undergraduate students.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Women_Enrollments_319-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Women_Enrollments-319">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Undergraduate and graduate students were drawn from all 50 states as well as 115 foreign countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
       <a href="#cite_note-320">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT received 17,909 applications for admission to the undergraduate Class of 2015; 1,742 were admitted (9.7 percent) and 1128 enrolled (64.8 percent).
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDS_139-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-CDS-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      19,446 applications were received for graduate and advanced degree program across all departments; 2,991 were admitted (15.4 percent) and 1,880 enrolled (62.8 percent).
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Admission_321-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Admission-321">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Interquartile_range" title="Interquartile range">
       interquartile range
      </a>
      on the SAT was 2090–2340 and 97 percent of students ranked in the top tenth of their high school graduating class.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDS_139-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-CDS-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      97 percent of the Class of 2012 returned as sophomores; 82 percent of the Class of 2007 graduated within 4 years, and 93 percent (91 percent of the men and 95 percent of the women) graduated within 6 years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDS_139-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-CDS-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CN_322-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CN-322">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Undergraduate tuition and fees total $40,732 and annual expenses are estimated at $52,507 as of 2012.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      62 percent of students received need-based financial aid in the form of scholarships and grants from federal, state, institutional, and external sources averaging $38,964 per student.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
         <span title="The text near this tag is dated.">
          needs update
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tuition_323-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Tuition-323">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Students were awarded a total of $102 million in scholarships and grants, primarily from institutional support ($84 million).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDS_139-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-CDS-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The annual increase in expenses has led to a student tradition (dating back to the 1960s) of tongue-in-cheek "tuition riots".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tuition_Riot_324-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Tuition_Riot-324">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT has been nominally
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Co-education" title="Co-education">
       co-educational
      </a>
      since admitting
      <a href="/wiki/Ellen_Swallow_Richards" title="Ellen Swallow Richards">
       Ellen Swallow Richards
      </a>
      in 1870. Richards also became the first female member of MIT's faculty, specializing in
      <a href="/wiki/Environmental_health" title="Environmental health">
       sanitary chemistry
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
       <a href="#cite_note-325">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Female students remained a minority prior to the completion of the first wing of a women's dormitory,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Katherine_Dexter_McCormick" title="Katherine Dexter McCormick">
       McCormick Hall
      </a>
      , in 1963.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
       <a href="#cite_note-326">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
       <a href="#cite_note-327">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
       <a href="#cite_note-328">
        [322]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Between 1993 and 2009, the proportion of women rose from 34 percent to 45 percent of undergraduates and from 20 percent to 31 percent of graduate students.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
       <a href="#cite_note-329">
        [323]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Women currently outnumber men in Biology, Brain &amp; Cognitive Sciences, Architecture, Urban Planning, and Biological Engineering.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Women_Enrollments_319-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Women_Enrollments-319">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A number of student deaths in the late 1990s and early 2000s resulted in considerable media attention to MIT's culture and student life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
       <a href="#cite_note-330">
        [324]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
       <a href="#cite_note-331">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the alcohol-related death of Scott Krueger in September 1997 as a new member at the
      <a href="/wiki/Phi_Gamma_Delta" title="Phi Gamma Delta">
       Phi Gamma Delta
      </a>
      fraternity,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Krueger_332-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Krueger-332">
        [326]
       </a>
      </sup>
      MIT began requiring all freshmen to live in the dormitory system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Krueger_332-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Krueger-332">
        [326]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
       <a href="#cite_note-333">
        [327]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 2000 suicide of MIT undergraduate
      <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Shin" title="Elizabeth Shin">
       Elizabeth Shin
      </a>
      drew attention to suicides at MIT and created a controversy over whether MIT had an unusually high suicide rate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shin_334-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Shin-334">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
       <a href="#cite_note-335">
        [329]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In late 2001 a task force's recommended improvements in student
      <a href="/wiki/Mental_health" title="Mental health">
       mental health
      </a>
      services were implemented,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
       <a href="#cite_note-336">
        [330]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
       <a href="#cite_note-337">
        [331]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including expanding staff and operating hours at the mental health center.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338">
       <a href="#cite_note-338">
        [332]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These and later cases were significant as well because they sought to prove the negligence and liability of university administrators
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/In_loco_parentis" title="In loco parentis">
        in loco parentis
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shin_334-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Shin-334">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Faculty_and_staff">
       Faculty and staff
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Faculty and staff">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_faculty" title="List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty">
       List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg/220px-Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg/330px-Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg/440px-Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ford-MIT_Nobel_Laureate_Lecture_Series_2000-09-18.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Institute Professors Emeriti and Nobel Laureates (from left to right)
        <a href="/wiki/Franco_Modigliani" title="Franco Modigliani">
         Franco Modigliani
        </a>
        (deceased),
        <a href="/wiki/Paul_Samuelson" title="Paul Samuelson">
         Paul Samuelson
        </a>
        (also deceased), and
        <a href="/wiki/Robert_Solow" title="Robert Solow">
         Robert Solow
        </a>
        (picture taken in 2000)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      As of 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , MIT had 1,030 faculty members, of whom 225 were women.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITFactFacStaff_4-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITFactFacStaff-4">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Faculty are responsible for lecturing classes, advising both graduate and undergraduate students, and sitting on academic committees, as well as conducting original research. Between 1964 and 2009, a total of seventeen faculty and staff members affiliated with MIT were awarded Nobel Prizes (thirteen in the last 25 years).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
       <a href="#cite_note-339">
        [333]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_laureates_by_university_affiliation" title="Nobel Prize laureates by university affiliation">
       MIT faculty members
      </a>
      past or present have won a total of twenty-seven Nobel Prizes, the majority in Economics or Physics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Faculty_Awards_340-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Faculty_Awards-340">
        [334]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of October 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , among current faculty and teaching staff there are 67
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guggenheim_Fellow" title="Guggenheim Fellow">
       Guggenheim Fellows
      </a>
      , 6
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fulbright_Scholar" title="Fulbright Scholar">
       Fulbright Scholars
      </a>
      , and 22
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MacArthur_Fellow" title="MacArthur Fellow">
       MacArthur Fellows
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MITFactFacStaff_4-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-MITFactFacStaff-4">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Faculty members who have made extraordinary contributions to their research field as well as the MIT community are granted appointments as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Institute_Professor" title="Institute Professor">
       Institute Professors
      </a>
      for the remainder of their tenures.
     </p>
     <p>
      A 1998 MIT study concluded that a systemic bias against female faculty existed in its School of Science,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341">
       <a href="#cite_note-341">
        [335]
       </a>
      </sup>
      although the study's methods were controversial.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342">
       <a href="#cite_note-342">
        [336]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
       <a href="#cite_note-343">
        [337]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the study, though, women have headed departments within the Schools of Science and of Engineering, and MIT has appointed several female vice presidents, although allegations of sexism continue to be made.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Male_Domain_344-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Male_Domain-344">
        [338]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Susan_Hockfield" title="Susan Hockfield">
       Susan Hockfield
      </a>
      , a molecular
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neurobiology" title="Neurobiology">
       neurobiologist
      </a>
      , was MIT's president from 2004 to 2012 and was the first woman to hold the post.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hockfield_159-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Hockfield-159">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Tenure outcomes have vaulted MIT into the national spotlight on several occasions. The 1984 dismissal of
      <a href="/wiki/David_F._Noble" title="David F. Noble">
       David F. Noble
      </a>
      , a historian of technology, became a
      <i>
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cause_c%C3%A9l%C3%A8bre" title="wikt:cause célèbre">
        cause célèbre
       </a>
      </i>
      about the extent to which academics are granted
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">
       freedom of speech
      </a>
      after he published several books and papers critical of MIT's and other research universities' reliance upon financial support from corporations and the military.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Noble_345-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Noble-345">
        [339]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Former materials science professor Gretchen Kalonji sued MIT in 1994 alleging that she was denied tenure because of sexual discrimination. Several years later, the lawsuit was settled with undisclosed payments, and establishment of a project to encourage women and minorities to seek faculty positions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Male_Domain_344-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Male_Domain-344">
        [338]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
       <a href="#cite_note-346">
        [340]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kalonji_347-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kalonji-347">
        [341]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1997, the
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Commission_Against_Discrimination" title="Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination">
       Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination
      </a>
      issued a probable cause finding supporting UMass Boston Professor James Jennings' allegations of racial discrimination after a senior faculty search committee in the Department of Urban Studies and Planning did not offer him reciprocal tenure.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jennings_348-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Jennings-348">
        [342]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2006–2007, MIT's denial of tenure to African-American stem cell scientist professor
      <a href="/wiki/James_Sherley" title="James Sherley">
       James Sherley
      </a>
      reignited accusations of racism in the tenure process, eventually leading to a protracted public dispute with the administration, a brief
      <a href="/wiki/Hunger_strike" title="Hunger strike">
       hunger strike
      </a>
      , and the resignation of Professor
      <a href="/wiki/Frank_L._Douglas" title="Frank L. Douglas">
       Frank L. Douglas
      </a>
      in protest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sherley_349-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sherley-349">
        [343]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
       <a href="#cite_note-350">
        [344]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">
        The Boston Globe
       </a>
      </i>
      reported on February 6, 2007: "Less than half of MIT's junior faculty members are granted tenure. After Sherley was initially denied tenure, his case was examined three times before the university established that neither racial discrimination nor conflict of interest affected the decision. Twenty-one of Sherley's colleagues issued a statement yesterday saying that the professor was treated fairly in tenure review."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
       <a href="#cite_note-351">
        [345]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT faculty members have often been recruited to lead other colleges and universities. Founding faculty member
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_W._Eliot" title="Charles W. Eliot">
       Charles W. Eliot
      </a>
      was recruited in 1869 to become president of Harvard University, a post he would hold for 40 years, during which he wielded considerable influence on both American higher education and secondary education. MIT alumnus and faculty member
      <a href="/wiki/George_Ellery_Hale" title="George Ellery Hale">
       George Ellery Hale
      </a>
      played a central role in the development of the
      <a href="/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology" title="California Institute of Technology">
       California Institute of Technology
      </a>
      (Caltech), and other faculty members have been key founders of
      <a href="/wiki/Franklin_W._Olin_College_of_Engineering" title="Franklin W. Olin College of Engineering">
       Franklin W. Olin College of Engineering
      </a>
      in nearby
      <a href="/wiki/Needham,_Massachusetts" title="Needham, Massachusetts">
       Needham, Massachusetts
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      As of 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , former provost
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_A._Brown" title="Robert A. Brown">
       Robert A. Brown
      </a>
      is president of
      <a href="/wiki/Boston_University" title="Boston University">
       Boston University
      </a>
      ; former provost
      <a href="/wiki/Mark_S._Wrighton" title="Mark S. Wrighton">
       Mark Wrighton
      </a>
      is chancellor of
      <a href="/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis" title="Washington University in St. Louis">
       Washington University in St. Louis
      </a>
      ; former associate provost
      <a href="/wiki/Alice_Gast" title="Alice Gast">
       Alice Gast
      </a>
      is president of
      <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_University" title="Lehigh University">
       Lehigh University
      </a>
      ; and former professor
      <a href="/wiki/Suh_Nam-pyo" title="Suh Nam-pyo">
       Suh Nam-pyo
      </a>
      is president of
      <a href="/wiki/KAIST" title="KAIST">
       KAIST
      </a>
      . Former dean of the School of Science
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_J._Birgeneau" title="Robert J. Birgeneau">
       Robert J. Birgeneau
      </a>
      was the chancellor of the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">
       University of California, Berkeley
      </a>
      (2004–2013); former professor
      <a href="/wiki/John_Maeda" title="John Maeda">
       John Maeda
      </a>
      was president of
      <a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island_School_of_Design" title="Rhode Island School of Design">
       Rhode Island School of Design
      </a>
      (RISD, 2008–2013); former professor
      <a href="/wiki/David_Baltimore" title="David Baltimore">
       David Baltimore
      </a>
      was president of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caltech" title="Caltech">
       Caltech
      </a>
      (1997–2006); and MIT alumnus and former assistant professor
      <a href="/wiki/Hans_Mark" title="Hans Mark">
       Hans Mark
      </a>
      served as chancellor of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Texas" title="University of Texas">
       University of Texas
      </a>
      system (1984–1992).
     </p>
     <p>
      In addition, faculty members have been recruited to lead governmental agencies; for example, former professor
      <a href="/wiki/Marcia_McNutt" title="Marcia McNutt">
       Marcia McNutt
      </a>
      is president of the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences" title="National Academy of Sciences">
       National Academy of Sciences
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
       <a href="#cite_note-352">
        [346]
       </a>
      </sup>
      urban studies professor
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xavier_de_Souza_Briggs" title="Xavier de Souza Briggs">
       Xavier de Souza Briggs
      </a>
      is currently the associate director of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_House_Office_of_Management_and_Budget" title="White House Office of Management and Budget">
       White House Office of Management and Budget
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
       <a href="#cite_note-353">
        [347]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and biology professor
      <a href="/wiki/Eric_Lander" title="Eric Lander">
       Eric Lander
      </a>
      is a co-chair of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President%27s_Council_of_Advisors_on_Science_and_Technology" title="President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology">
       President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
       <a href="#cite_note-354">
        [348]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2013, faculty member
      <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Moniz" title="Ernest Moniz">
       Ernest Moniz
      </a>
      was nominated by President Obama and later confirmed as
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Energy" title="United States Secretary of Energy">
       United States Secretary of Energy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes-nominee_355-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nytimes-nominee-355">
        [349]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356">
       <a href="#cite_note-356">
        [350]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Former professor Hans Mark served as Secretary of the Air Force from 1979 to 1981. Alumna and Institute Professor Sheila Widnall served as Secretary of the Air Force between 1993 and 1997, making her the first female Secretary of the Air Force and first woman to lead an entire branch of the US military in the Department of Defense.
     </p>
     <p>
      Based on feedback from employees, MIT was ranked #7 as a place to work, among US colleges and universities as of 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glassdoor_357-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Glassdoor-357">
        [351]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Surveys cited a "smart", "creative", "friendly" environment, noting that the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Work-life_balance" title="Work-life balance">
       work-life balance
      </a>
      tilts towards a "strong work ethic", but complaining about "low pay".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GlassdoorMIT_358-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GlassdoorMIT-358">
        [352]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_alumni">
       Notable alumni
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Notable alumni">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_alumni" title="List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni">
       List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Many of MIT's over 120,000 alumni have had considerable success in scientific research, public service, education, and business. As of 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , 27 MIT alumni have
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_alumni#Alumni_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni">
       won the Nobel Prize
      </a>
      , 47 have been selected as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhodes_Scholar" title="Rhodes Scholar">
       Rhodes Scholars
      </a>
      , and 61 have been selected as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marshall_Scholar" title="Marshall Scholar">
       Marshall Scholars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRAwardsHonors_359-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IRAwardsHonors-359">
        [353]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Alumni in American politics and public service include former
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Federal_Reserve" title="Chairman of the Federal Reserve">
       Chairman of the Federal Reserve
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_Bernanke" title="Ben Bernanke">
       Ben Bernanke
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Massachusetts's 1st congressional district">
       MA-1
      </a>
      Representative
      <a href="/wiki/John_Olver" title="John Olver">
       John Olver
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/California%27s_13th_congressional_district" title="California's 13th congressional district">
       CA-13
      </a>
      Representative
      <a href="/wiki/Pete_Stark" title="Pete Stark">
       Pete Stark
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_National_Economic_Council" title="United States National Economic Council">
       National Economic Council
      </a>
      chairman
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lawrence_H._Summers" title="Lawrence H. Summers">
       Lawrence H. Summers
      </a>
      , and former
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Economic_Advisors" title="Council of Economic Advisors">
       Council of Economic Advisors
      </a>
      chairwoman
      <a href="/wiki/Christina_Romer" title="Christina Romer">
       Christina Romer
      </a>
      . MIT alumni in international politics include
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs_Minister_of_Iran" title="Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran">
       Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ali_Akbar_Salehi" title="Ali Akbar Salehi">
       Ali Akbar Salehi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">
       Israeli Prime Minister
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">
       Benjamin Netanyahu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">
       President of Colombia
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Virgilio_Barco_Vargas" title="Virgilio Barco Vargas">
       Virgilio Barco Vargas
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="President of the European Central Bank">
       President of the European Central Bank
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Mario_Draghi" title="Mario Draghi">
       Mario Draghi
      </a>
      , Governor of the Reserve Bank of India
      <a href="/wiki/Raghuram_Rajan" title="Raghuram Rajan">
       Raghuram Rajan
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Affairs" title="Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs">
       British Foreign Minister
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/David_Miliband" title="David Miliband">
       David Miliband
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Greece" title="Prime Minister of Greece">
       Greek Prime Minister
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Papademos" title="Lucas Papademos">
       Lucas Papademos
      </a>
      , former
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Secretary_General" title="UN Secretary General">
       UN Secretary General
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">
       Kofi Annan
      </a>
      , and former
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Iraq" title="Council of Ministers of Iraq">
       Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Chalabi" title="Ahmed Chalabi">
       Ahmed Chalabi
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      MIT alumni founded or co-founded many notable companies, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Noyce" title="Robert Noyce">
       Intel
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/James_Smith_McDonnell" title="James Smith McDonnell">
       McDonnell
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Donald_Wills_Douglas,_Sr." title="Donald Wills Douglas, Sr.">
       Douglas
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cecil_Howard_Green" title="Cecil Howard Green">
       Texas Instruments
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Metcalfe" title="Robert Metcalfe">
       3Com
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Viterbi" title="Andrew Viterbi">
       Qualcomm
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Amar_Bose" title="Amar Bose">
       Bose
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vannevar_Bush" title="Vannevar Bush">
       Raytheon
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fred_C._Koch" title="Fred C. Koch">
       Koch Industries
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Willard_Rockwell" title="Willard Rockwell">
       Rockwell International
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_A._Swanson" title="Robert A. Swanson">
       Genentech
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Drew_Houston" title="Drew Houston">
       Dropbox
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/John_Thompson_Dorrance" title="John Thompson Dorrance">
       Campbell Soup
      </a>
      . According to the British newspaper,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">
        The Guardian
       </a>
      </i>
      , "a survey of living MIT alumni found that they have formed 25,800 companies, employing more than three million people including about a quarter of the workforce of Silicon Valley. Those firms collectively generate global revenues of about $1.9 trillion (£1.2 trillion) a year. If MIT were a country, it would have the 11th highest GDP of any nation in the world."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Entrepreneur_360-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Entrepreneur-360">
        [354]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kauffman_361-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kauffman-361">
        [355]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
       <a href="#cite_note-362">
        [356]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Prominent institutions of higher education have been led by MIT alumni, including the
      <a href="/wiki/David_S._Saxon" title="David S. Saxon">
       University of California
      </a>
      system,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lawrence_H._Summers" title="Lawrence H. Summers">
       Harvard University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rahmat_Shoureshi" title="Rahmat Shoureshi">
       New York Institute of Technology
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/William_R._Brody" title="William R. Brody">
       Johns Hopkins University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Subra_Suresh" title="Subra Suresh">
       Carnegie Mellon University
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Larry_Bacow" title="Larry Bacow">
       Tufts University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Albert_J._Simone" title="Albert J. Simone">
       Rochester Institute of Technology
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/John_Maeda" title="John Maeda">
       Rhode Island School of Design (RISD)
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Aoun" title="Joseph Aoun">
       Northeastern University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Adil_Najam" title="Adil Najam">
       Lahore University of Management Sciences
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shirley_Jackson_(physicist)" title="Shirley Jackson (physicist)">
       Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Garza_Sada" title="Eugenio Garza Sada">
       Tecnológico de Monterrey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Martin_C._Jischke" title="Martin C. Jischke">
       Purdue University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/T._Marshall_Hahn" title="T. Marshall Hahn">
       Virginia Polytechnic Institute
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Suh_Nam-pyo" title="Suh Nam-pyo">
       KAIST
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Pervez_Hoodbhoy" title="Pervez Hoodbhoy">
       Quaid-e-Azam University
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music" title="Berklee College of Music">
       Berklee College of Music
      </a>
      , the largest independent college of contemporary music in the world, was founded and led by MIT alumnus
      <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Berk" title="Lawrence Berk">
       Lawrence Berk
      </a>
      for more than three decades.
     </p>
     <p>
      More than one third of the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_NASA_missions#Human_spaceflight" title="List of NASA missions">
       United States' manned spaceflights
      </a>
      have included
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_alumni#Alumni_Astronauts" title="List of Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni">
       MIT-educated astronauts
      </a>
      (among them
      <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">
       Apollo 11
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Lunar_Module" title="Apollo Lunar Module">
       Lunar Module
      </a>
      Pilot
      <a href="/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin" title="Buzz Aldrin">
       Buzz Aldrin
      </a>
      ), more than any university excluding the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_service_academies" title="United States service academies">
       United States service academies
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
       <a href="#cite_note-363">
        [357]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Alumnus and former faculty member
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qian_Xuesen" title="Qian Xuesen">
       Qian Xuesen
      </a>
      was instrumental in the PRC rocket program.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364">
       <a href="#cite_note-364">
        [358]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Noted alumni in non-scientific fields include author
      <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Lofting" title="Hugh Lofting">
       Hugh Lofting
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
       <a href="#cite_note-365">
        [359]
       </a>
      </sup>
      sculptor
      <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Chester_French" title="Daniel Chester French">
       Daniel Chester French
      </a>
      , guitarist
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Scholz" title="Tom Scholz">
       Tom Scholz
      </a>
      of the band
      <a href="/wiki/Boston_(band)" title="Boston (band)">
       Boston
      </a>
      , the British
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">
        BBC
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/ITN" title="ITN">
        ITN
       </a>
      </i>
      correspondent and political advisor
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/David_Walter_(British_journalist_and_politician)" title="David Walter (British journalist and politician)">
       David Walter
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
        The New York Times
       </a>
      </i>
      columnist and Nobel Prize Winning economist
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_Krugman" title="Paul Krugman">
       Paul Krugman
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bell_Curve" title="The Bell Curve">
        The Bell Curve
       </a>
      </i>
      author
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Murray_(political_scientist)" title="Charles Murray (political scientist)">
       Charles Murray
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_building" title="United States Supreme Court building">
       United States Supreme Court building
      </a>
      architect
      <a href="/wiki/Cass_Gilbert" title="Cass Gilbert">
       Cass Gilbert
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WDL_366-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WDL-366">
        [360]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pritzker_Prize" title="Pritzker Prize">
       Pritzker Prize
      </a>
      -winning architects
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I.M._Pei" title="I.M. Pei">
       I.M. Pei
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Bunshaft" title="Gordon Bunshaft">
       Gordon Bunshaft
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional center">

          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">

          </a>
          1986-1990
          <a href="/wiki/Virgilio_Barco_Vargas" title="Virgilio Barco Vargas">
           Virgilio Barco Vargas
          </a>
          , SB 1943 (Civil Engineering)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">

         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ben_Bernanke_official_portrait.jpg">

          <a href="/wiki/Ben_Bernanke" title="Ben Bernanke">

          </a>
          , PhD 1979 (Economics)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">

          <a href="/wiki/Richard_Feynman" title="Richard Feynman">

          </a>
          , SB 1939 (Physics)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th,_2008-8.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3194" data-file-width="2592" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg/97px-Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg/146px-Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg/195px-Paul_Krugman-press_conference_Dec_07th%2C_2008-8.jpg 2x" width="97"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          Economics Nobel laureate
          <a href="/wiki/Paul_Krugman" title="Paul Krugman">
           Paul Krugman
          </a>
          , PhD 1977 (Economics)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="4945" data-file-width="3690" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg/89px-National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg/134px-National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg/179px-National_Women%27s_Suffrage_Association.jpg 2x" width="89"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          Biologist, suffragist, philanthropist
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Katherine_McCormick" title="Katherine McCormick">
           Katherine Dexter McCormick
          </a>
          (left), SB 1904 (Biology)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ronald_mcnair.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="245" data-file-width="199" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ronald_mcnair.jpg/97px-Ronald_mcnair.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ronald_mcnair.jpg/146px-Ronald_mcnair.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ronald_mcnair.jpg/195px-Ronald_mcnair.jpg 2x" width="97"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/STS-51-L" title="STS-51-L">
           Challenger astronaut
          </a>
          and physicist
          <a href="/wiki/Ronald_McNair" title="Ronald McNair">
           Ronald McNair
          </a>
          , PhD 1976 (Physics)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="412" data-file-width="291" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg/85px-Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg/127px-Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg/169px-Benjamin_Netanyahu.jpg 2x" width="85"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          Israeli Prime Minister
          <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">
           Benjamin Netanyahu
          </a>
          , SB 1975 (Architecture), SM 1976 (Management)

      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
       <div style="width: 155px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I.M._Pei.JPG">

      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">

          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine,_December_27,_1926.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="527" data-file-width="400" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg/91px-Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg/137px-Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg/182px-Alfred_P._Sloan_on_the_cover_of_TIME_Magazine%2C_December_27%2C_1926.jpg 2x" width="91"/>
          </a>
         </div>

          </a>

          </a>
          , SB 1895 (Electrical Engineering)

          </a>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="References">

      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Notes">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-126">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-126">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The friezes of the marble-clad buildings surrounding Killian Court are carved in large Roman letters with the names of
         <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">
          Aristotle
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">
          Newton
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Louis_Pasteur" title="Louis Pasteur">
          Pasteur
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Lavoisier" title="Antoine Lavoisier">
          Lavoisier
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">
          Faraday
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Archimedes" title="Archimedes">
          Archimedes
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
          da Vinci
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">
          Darwin
         </a>
         , and
         <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">
          Copernicus
         </a>
         ; each of these names is surmounted by a cluster of appropriately related names in smaller letters. Lavoisier, for example, is placed in the company of
         <a href="/wiki/Robert_Boyle" title="Robert Boyle">
          Boyle
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cavendish" title="Henry Cavendish">
          Cavendish
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Priestley" title="Joseph Priestley">
          Priestley
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/John_Dalton" title="John Dalton">
          Dalton
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Louis_Gay-Lussac" title="Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac">
          Gay Lussac
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J%C3%B6ns_Jakob_Berzelius" title="Jöns Jakob Berzelius">
          Berzelius
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_W%C3%B6hler" title="Friedrich Wöhler">
          Woehler
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Justus_von_Liebig" title="Justus von Liebig">
          Liebig
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Robert_Bunsen" title="Robert Bunsen">
          Bunsen
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Mendeleev" title="Dmitri Mendeleev">
          Mendelejeff
         </a>
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">
           sic
          </a>
         </i>
         ],
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sir_William_Henry_Perkin" title="Sir William Henry Perkin">
          Perkin
         </a>
         , and
         <a href="/wiki/Jacobus_Henricus_van_%27t_Hoff" title="Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff">
          van't Hoff
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
          <a href="#cite_note-124">
           [124]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TechNames_125-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-TechNames-125">
           [125]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-155">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-155">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology (HST) offers joint MD, MD-PhD, or Medical Engineering degrees in collaboration with
         <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Medical_School" title="Harvard Medical School">
          Harvard Medical School
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
          <a href="#cite_note-154">
           [153]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-169">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-169">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Course numbers are sometimes presented in
         <a href="/wiki/Roman_numerals" title="Roman numerals">
          Roman numerals
         </a>
         , e.g. "Course XVIII" for mathematics.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enrollments_167-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Enrollments-167">
           [165]
          </a>
         </sup>
         At least one MIT style guide now discourages this usage.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
          <a href="#cite_note-168">
           [166]
          </a>
         </sup>
         Also, some Course numbers have been re-assigned over time, so that the subject area of a degree may depend on the year it was awarded.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Butcher_165-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-Butcher-165">
           [163]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-193">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-193">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Figure includes 196 students working on Harvard degrees only.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-218">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-218">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="/wiki/Vannevar_Bush" title="Vannevar Bush">
          Vannevar Bush
         </a>
         was the director of the
         <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Scientific_Research_and_Development" title="Office of Scientific Research and Development">
          Office of Scientific Research and Development
         </a>
         and general advisor to
         <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">
          Franklin D. Roosevelt
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harry_Truman" title="Harry Truman">
          Harry Truman
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/James_Rhyne_Killian" title="James Rhyne Killian">
          James Rhyne Killian
         </a>
         was Special Assistant for Science and Technology for
         <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">
          Dwight D. Eisenhower
         </a>
         , and
         <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Wiesner" title="Jerome Wiesner">
          Jerome Wiesner
         </a>
         advised
         <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">
          John F. Kennedy
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyndon_Johnson" title="Lyndon Johnson">
          Lyndon Johnson
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
          <a href="#cite_note-217">
           [213]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-228">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-228">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         MIT's Building 7 and Harvard's Johnston Gate, the traditional entrances to each school, are 1.72 miles (2.77 km) apart along
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Boston)" title="Massachusetts Avenue (Boston)">
          Massachusetts Avenue
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>

        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         As of June 30, 2015.
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/EndowmentFiles/2015_NCSE_Endowment_Market_Values.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           "U.S. and Canadian Institutions Listed by Fiscal Year (FY) 2015 Endowment Market Value and Change in Endowment Market Value from FY 2014 to FY 2015"
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          . National Association of College and University Business Officers and Commonfund Institute. 2016.
         </cite>

        <span class="reference-text">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.btitle=Founding+Document%3A+1968+MIT+Faculty+Statement&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ucsusa.org%2Fucs%2Fabout%2Ffounding-document-1968-mit-faculty-statement.html&amp;rft.pub=Union+of+Concerned+Scientists%2C+USA&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-67">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-67">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fred_Hechinger" title="Fred Hechinger">
           Hechinger, Fred
          </a>
          (November 9, 1969). "Tension Over Issue of Defense Research".
          <i>
           The New York Times
          </i>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=Tension+Over+Issue+of+Defense+Research&amp;rft.aufirst=Fred&amp;rft.aulast=Hechinger&amp;rft.date=1969-11-09&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-68">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-68">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Stevens, William (May 5, 1969). "MIT Curb on Secret Projects Reflects Growing Antimilitary Feeling Among Universities' Researchers".
          <i>
           The New York Times
          </i>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=MIT+Curb+on+Secret+Projects+Reflects+Growing+Antimilitary+Feeling+Among+Universities%27+Researchers&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.aulast=Stevens&amp;rft.date=1969-05-05&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-69">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-69">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          Warsh, David (June 1, 1999).
          <a class="external text" href="http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/1999/johnson-0609.html" rel="nofollow">
           "A tribute to MIT's Howard Johnson"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           The Boston Globe
          </i>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            April 4,
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           At a critical time in the late 1960s,
           <a href="/wiki/Howard_Wesley_Johnson" title="Howard Wesley Johnson">
            Johnson
           </a>
           stood up to the forces of campus rebellion at MIT. Many university presidents were destroyed by the troubles. Only
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edward_Levi" title="Edward Levi">
            Edward Levi
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">
            University of Chicago
           </a>
           president, had comparable success guiding his institution to a position of greater strength and unity after the turmoil.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=A+tribute+to+MIT%27s+Howard+Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.aulast=Warsh&amp;rft.date=1999-06-01&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fweb.mit.edu%2Fnewsoffice%2F1999%2Fjohnson-0609.html&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Boston+Globe&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-70">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         '
         <i>
          <a href="#cite_ref-70">
           ^
          </a>
         </i>
         <b>
          <i>
           <span class="reference-text">
            <a class="external text" href="http://tech.mit.edu/V91/PDF/V91-N55.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             'Battering Ram: The occupation of the president's office',
             <b>
              The Tech
              <i>
               , 14/12/71 p4
              </i>
             </b>
            </a>
            and
            <a class="external text" href="http://tech.mit.edu/V92/PDF/V92-N28.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             The Tech
             <i>
              , 4/8/72
             </i>
            </a>
            ;
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=x3ertj1IcaAC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;source=gbs_ge_summary_r&amp;cad=0#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             M.Albert, Remembering Tomorrow
            </a>
            p9, 97-99;
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.democracynow.org/2007/4/17/from_sds_to_life_after_capitalism" rel="nofollow">
             'Michael Albert interview', 17/4/07
            </a>
            ; G.Katsiaficas,
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.eroseffect.com/articles/holdingthecenter.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             'Review of Howard Johnson's Holding the Center
            </a>
            ; S.Shalom,
            <a class="external text" href="http://nova.wpunj.edu/newpolitics/issue23/shalom23.htm" rel="nofollow">
             'A flawed political biography'
            </a>
            ,
            <i>
             New Politics
            </i>
            , Issue 23.
           </span>
          </i>
         </b>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-71">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         '
         <i>
          <a href="#cite_ref-71">
           ^
          </a>
         </i>
         <b>
          <i>
           <span class="reference-text">
            <a class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nD4QZFubjaY" rel="nofollow">
             November Actions youtube extract'
            </a>
            . See also:
            <a class="external text" href="https://webmuseum.mit.edu/detail.php?module=subjects&amp;type=browse&amp;id=10&amp;term=Activism&amp;page=1&amp;kv=3&amp;record=0&amp;module=subjects" rel="nofollow">
             MIT Museum photos of student activism, 1960s/1970s
            </a>
            .
           </span>

         </b>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-72">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          <a href="#cite_ref-72">

        <span class="reference-text">

          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130220043833/http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?tp=&amp;arnumber=145317&amp;contentType=Journals+%26+Magazines&amp;sortType%3Dasc_p_Sequence%26filter%3DAND%28p_IS_Number%3A3898%29" rel="nofollow">

        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Jarzombek1_123-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>

        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          <a href="/wiki/Mark_Jarzombek" title="Mark Jarzombek">
           Jarzombek, Mark
          </a>
          (2004).
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=QiwRGc3E7Z8C&amp;printsec=frontcover" rel="nofollow">

           ^

          . p. B1.
         </cite>

       <li id="cite_note-164">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-164">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.mitadmissions.org/topics/learning/majors_minors/index.shtml" rel="nofollow">
           "Majors &amp; Minors"
          </a>
          . MIT Admissions Office
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            August 13,
           </span>
           2008
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           MIT is organized into academic departments, or Courses, which you will often hear referred to by their Course number or acronym.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.btitle=Majors+%26+Minors&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mitadmissions.org%2Ftopics%2Flearning%2Fmajors_minors%2Findex.shtml&amp;rft.pub=MIT+Admissions+Office&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         <cite class="citation web">
          Coughlan, Sean (15 September 2014).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.com/news/business-29086590" rel="nofollow">
           "What makes a global top 10 university?"
          </a>

            BBC News
           </a>
          </i>
          .
          <q>
           It's the third year in a row that [MIT] … has been top of the QS World University Rankings. The biggest single factor in the QS rankings is academic reputation … calculated by surveying more than 60,000 academics… Universities with an established name and a strong brand are likely to do better.
          </q>

       <li id="cite_note-210">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-210">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation journal">
          "A Survey of New England: A Concentration of Talent".
          <i>
           The Economist
          </i>
          . August 8, 1987.
          <q>
           MIT for a long time... stood virtually alone as a university that embraced rather than shunned industry.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=A+Survey+of+New+England%3A+A+Concentration+of+Talent&amp;rft.date=1987-08-08&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-211">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-211">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Roberts, Edward B. (1991). "An Environment for Entrepreneurs".
          <i>
           MIT: Shaping the Future
          </i>
          . Cambridge, MA:
          <a href="/wiki/MIT_Press" title="MIT Press">
           MIT Press
          </a>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0262631415" title="Special:BookSources/0262631415">
           0262631415
          </a>
          .
          <q>
           The war made necessary the formation of new working coalitions... between these technologists and government officials. These changes were especially noteworthy at MIT.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=An+Environment+for+Entrepreneurs&amp;rft.aufirst=Edward+B.&amp;rft.aulast=Roberts&amp;rft.btitle=MIT%3A+Shaping+the+Future&amp;rft.date=1991&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.isbn=0262631415&amp;rft.place=Cambridge%2C+MA&amp;rft.pub=MIT+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-212">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-212">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Shlaes, Amity (May 14, 2008). "From the Ponderosa to the Googleplex: How Americans match money to ideas".
          <i>
           State Department Press Release
          </i>
          . U.S. Department of State.
          <q>
           Griswold, [MIT president] Compton, and various politicians handpicked Doriot to head American Research &amp; Development, a new firm that would invest in [the] small, innovative companies that had been underserved by traditional capital markets.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.atitle=From+the+Ponderosa+to+the+Googleplex%3A+How+Americans+match+money+to+ideas&amp;rft.aufirst=Amity&amp;rft.aulast=Shlaes&amp;rft.date=2008-05-14&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=State+Department+Press+Release&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>

       <li id="cite_note-213">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          <a class="external text" href="http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/publication/2008/05/20080512161121jmnamdeirf0.424679.html" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          .
          <i>
           New England Business
          </i>
          . Boston. p. 15.
          <q>
           Compton co-founded in 1946 what is believed to be the nation's first venture capital company.…  [He] and a group led by a Harvard professor [Doriot] founded one of the first venture capital companies, American Research &amp; Development Corp.

        <span class="reference-text">

        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/28/us-akamai-tech-results-idUSKBN0NJ2IV20150428" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          . Reuters. April 28, 2015.

       <li id="cite_note-292">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-292">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a href="/wiki/Marilee_Jones" title="Marilee Jones">
           Jones, Marilee
          </a>
          .
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061107035149/http://web.mit.edu/admissions/pdf/MITinstructions.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           "MIT freshman application &amp; financial aid information"
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          . MIT Admissions Office. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://web.mit.edu/admissions/pdf/MITinstructions.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          on November 7, 2006
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            January 2,
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           We are a meritocracy. We judge each other by our ideas, our creativity and our accomplishments, not by who our families are.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.aufirst=Marilee&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.btitle=MIT+freshman+application+%26+financial+aid+information&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fweb.mit.edu%2Fadmissions%2Fpdf%2FMITinstructions.pdf&amp;rft.pub=MIT+Admissions+Office&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-293">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-293">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          Bernanke, Ben S. (June 9, 2006).
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061007204443/http://www.federalreserve.gov/boarddocs/speeches/2006/20060609/default.htm" rel="nofollow">
           "2006 Commencement Speech at MIT"
          </a>
          . Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.federalreserve.gov/boardDocs/speeches/2006/20060609/default.htm" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          on October 7, 2006
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            January 2,
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           Mathematical approaches to economics have at times been criticized as lacking in practical value. Yet the MIT Economics Department has trained many economists who have played leading roles in government and in the private sector, including the current heads of four central banks: those of
           <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Chile" title="Central Bank of Chile">
            Chile
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_Israelsrael&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bank of Israelsrael (page does not exist)">
            Bank of Israelsrael
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Banca_d%27Italiataly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Banca d'Italiataly (page does not exist)">
            Banca d'Italiataly
           </a>
           , and, I might add, the
           <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System" title="Federal Reserve System">
            10=United States
           </a>
           .
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben+S.&amp;rft.aulast=Bernanke&amp;rft.btitle=2006+Commencement+Speech+at+MIT&amp;rft.date=2006-06-09&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.federalreserve.gov%2FboardDocs%2Fspeeches%2F2006%2F20060609%2Fdefault.htm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-294">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-294">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2001/commdegrees.html" rel="nofollow">
           "No honorary degrees is an MIT tradition going back to... Thomas Jefferson"
          </a>
          . MIT News Office. June 8, 2001
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            May 7,
           </span>
           2006
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           MIT's founder,
           <a href="/wiki/William_Barton_Rogers" title="William Barton Rogers">
            William Barton Rogers
           </a>
           , regarded the practice of giving honorary degrees as 'literary almsgiving ...of spurious merit and noisy popularity...'
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMassachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;rft.btitle=No+honorary+degrees+is+an+MIT+tradition+going+back+to...+Thomas+Jefferson&amp;rft.date=2001-06-08&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fweb.mit.edu%2Fnewsoffice%2F2001%2Fcommdegrees.html&amp;rft.pub=MIT+News+Office&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

        <span class="reference-text">

          <i>
